title: Now, instead of fearing Jumanji, the audience must want to become a character in the game, since you become a great hero and gain superpowers
text: Produced by Columbia Pictures, Matt Tolmach Productions, Radar Pictures and Seven Bucks Productions and distributed by Sony Pictures Entertainment, this sequel to the classic Jumanji (1995) stars Dwayne Johnson, Kevin Hart, Jack Black, Karen Gillan and Nick Jonas. Always remembered for the special effects and wild animals that the evil game brought to the real world, the 1995 feature brought a mixture of comedy and suspense that sets the tone of adventure of the 1990s. More than 20 years later, the franchise is reborn without this footprint, more frantic, with few animals, video game aesthetics and focused on comedy.In Jumanji: Welcome to the Jungle, four teenagers find a video game that takes place in a tropical forest. Excited about the game, they choose their avatars for the challenge, but an unexpected event causes them to be transported into the fictional universe, becoming the characters of the adventure.Jumanji: Welcome to the Jungle, thankfully, it doesn't usually appeal to cheap nostalgia or try to remind you, on a recurring basis, that this is a sequence from a 90's movie. The feature has a microcosm and a tone that is partly its own, more like current comedies than Robin Williams' Jumanji - which can be a problem depending on your expectations. The new version distances itself a lot from the original work of Chris Van Allsburg, author of the book, and only keeps small references, just to justify the definition as a sequel, and to attract the older audience that watched the original. In its second version, Jumanji is no longer a board game. In fact, the game received an update and was transformed into a video game to suit the new generation. Unlike the original film, Welcome to the Jungle is divided into two very distinct parts: one presenting the characters in the real world and the other with their respective avatars within the video game.When announced it was the fact that now, the characters would enter Jumanji through a video game, breaking all the magic of the original board. Fortunately, even this has been well worked out and the transition from one format to another is well justified, showing that Jumanji is a game that does everything to be played. In the first half hour, director Jake Kasdan quickly introduces the four characters in a fun and light rhythm, reminiscent of excerpts from The Club of Five and Mean Girls, with their respective defects established right away (and consequent defined arcs) will enter a unforgettable journey when they go to detention and end up with an updated version of Jumanji. By selecting different characters, each of the young people will be transported to the Jumanji universe and there will undergo transformations that will change their perspectives on who they are and what roles they have in real life. First of all, however, the goal will be to save that jungle from the fearsome Van Pelt (Bobby Cannavale), an extremely generic and boring villain who, inexorably, ends up becoming a parody of himself, clearly unintentionally.After the presentation of the real world characters, unlike the original film, the narrative structure throws us into the jungle that Alan Parrish, played by the late Robin Williams, was transported during those 26 years, without bringing, as previously done, the jungle to the real life. If the same event were repeated, we would certainly lose all the margin of originality that could be achieved, while here we have a story that deepens the forest and brings with it a sense of novelty, even exploring known narrative paths. This also opens up possibilities for Alan Parrish himself, and, of course, his interpreter, to be lightly honored with an exciting score. In the essence of Welcome to the Jungle, this is a continuation that pays tribute to the splendid figure that was Williams, in terms of his smiles and celebrations.In Jumanji's jungle, the best idea of the script is to notice how the roles are reversed creating good opportunities for humor: real-life nerds become Dr. Smolder Bravestone (Dwayne Johnson) and Ruby Roundhouse (Karen Gillian), the strong characters of the game. Popular people receive support avatars: the athlete is reduced to playing Bravestone biologist and henchman, Moose Finbar (Kevin Hart), while the girl adored at school enters the shoes of cartographer Shelly Oberon (Jack Black). The artifice of changing the body gives good material for the actors to play with and most of the initial jokes work with it. It's fun to see The Rock surprise itself with its muscles and not knowing how to act in battle, but Jack Black is the one who steals the show in the film. Playing a selfish girl, the actor creates very funny mannerisms and delivers a comic interpretation in the right measure, with conscious exaggerations that amuse and almost never fall into the shame of others - something that could easily happen to such a character.The comedy varies greatly in both tone and quality. The duo The Rock and Kevin Hart head the film with the same kind of comedy we saw in One and a Half: lots of jokes with the difference in size of the two, Hart screaming thin in trouble, jokes with sexual organs and so on. Although not bad, the duo is the weakest comic part of the feature. Gillian's character, who generated a lot of controversy when appearing in the film's publicity photos in very short clothes, has her moments and the girl's constant dissatisfaction with the provocative look of her avatar develops a criticism of the objectification of the woman's figure in games and entertainment as a whole (Tomb Raider's reference to Lara Croft is obvious). The actress knows how to be funny, beautiful and sensual as few can.While focusing on comedy, the new Jumanji forgets a little about the action. When he does, he is unable to provide scenes that are impactful or stay with the viewer until the end of the film. The idea really doesn't seem to stick to explosions, chases or fights - the whole action part of Welcome to the Jungle is in the background. And if there is a fan of the original feature who appreciates Joe Johnston's suspense, it will come out disappointed. The proposal here is to be a light adventure, uncompromised and directed towards comedy. In addition, the missions are not very well built, and the story is beyond forgettable, with a predictable and formulaic ending, obeying the rules of limited lives and skills / weaknesses in a bureaucratic way. In parallel to the villainous blasé of Cannavale, it is interesting that much of the character's background is given through the cut scenes already mentioned.The film can be as predictable as you might think. The plot of the film does what it needs, it takes the characters from point A to point B, and that's all you need to do. The fact that the characters are jokingly trapped in a video game, not taking themselves seriously. There are many moments when Chris McKenna's script has fun with basic clichés that only make sense in games. The film laughs at cut scenes entering and leaving the characters confused, NPC dialogues purposely expository to play with the way video game characters are written, among several other virtuous games with the media.Although it does not take itself seriously, the work sins in several points: the villain is bad, there is no development and much less a motivation besides "taking over the world". Many jokes are repeated over and over, which makes the mood tiring at times; the writers also don't seem to believe in the viewer's ability and explain extremely basic things about the plot countless times and in the silliest ways possible. The script takes many unnecessary turns, to the point that unfounded challenges are created in the final half of the film. The few moments when they try to create a dramatic arc are also meager - and Nick Jonas' acting as Alex doesn't help. Every part where the film tries to create a meaningful relationship for the virtual characters is shallow and poorly developed and that is a huge problem in the outcome of the film.Jumanji is a symbol of childhood for many and with the reboot it should continue to be, now for a new generation. Only the name, the game and one or another creature are kept from the original. Jumanji's continuation is, above all, a pleasant surprise, extremely fun, with a wittiness that refers to both the original film and the modern video games. With good action scenes handled by director Jake Kasdan, Welcome to the Jungle is guaranteed fun. Did you need to have the name Jumanji and get hold of an already known brand? No. Unfortunately, the darker tone and the harmless touches of fear that the game brought to the cinema are neglected. Now, instead of fearing Jumanji, the audience must want to become a character in the game, since you become a great hero, gain superpowers and face threats that scare little the most fearful of warriors. The script choices, always following the easiest ways to resolve conflicts, create a film that is unlikely to mark an era, like the original feature film. It is a pastime, clearly unpretentious, which does not trust the intelligence of its viewer at various times. Despite having some Easter eggs from the original 'Jumanji', Jake Kasdan delivers an original adventure that manages to innovate, as well as the title game.

title: Welcome to the Jungle

title: Hit and Miss
text:
Braveheart, Seven, Heat, Die Hard, Goldeneye, Toy Story, 12 Monkeys, Bad Boys, Desperado, Ace Ventura, Mortal Combat, Judge Dredd, Waterworld, Babe, Apollo 13- whew, what a year 1995 was in Hollywood. My favorite though in that year was the Robin William classic, Jumanji. A fantasy adventure based on the 1981 children's book, it featured a board game with a magical twist, along with a typically endearing performance by Robin Williams. Targeting the Christmas holiday crowd, and with rhinos thundering down the streets, it made tons of money, even with relatively rudimentary visual effects. Given the state of VFX today, and the solid demand for good family fun in December, I was surprised that a sequel for Jumanji was not attempted all these years. Oh wait, there was Zathura: A Space Adventure in 2005. Right.Circa Christmas 2017, and we finally have a sequel starring everyone's favorite eyebrow. Set 21 years after the original movie, the premise is slightly different this time. 4 teenagers get sucked into the jungle world of Jumanji, and they need to play as game characters and win to return back home. Sounds simple? Director Jake Kasdan livens things up by getting the teenagers to play avatars that are opposites of the real life characters. So nerdy Spencer Gilpin becomes the heroic Smolder Bravestone played by Dwayne Johnson, jock Fridge becomes wimpy sidekick Franklin Finbar played by Kevin Hart, shy Martha becomes Ruby Roundhouse (played by Karen Gillan) who is basically a Lara Croft rip-off, and popular college babe Bethany transforms into overweight cartographer Sheldon Oberon (Jack Black). Throw in hippos, rhinos, elephants, jaguars, and snakes into the mix and bingo you can justify the title. There is of course a villain in the mix, but it is kind of immaterial. This is a family movie, releasing in Christmas, of people playing video game characters, so we all know how it goes.In short, nothing exceptionally original- it is Breakfast Club + 13 going to 30 + Indiana Jones + Jack Black Speaking of Jack Black, he is hilarious as a teenage girl, and we all know that Johnson and Kevin Hart have awesome chemistry- watch Central Intelligence for an even better showcase. The movie is fast paced, the script is funny, the special effects are as good as it gets, but the story lacks imagination, and the characters are way under-developed. True the kids learn something about life by playing different avatars, but that's about it. I kept going back to the original, and by god that was a classic! The game coming into our lives is certainly more interesting than us in a game.Having said that Jumanji: Welcome to the Jungle is a good one time watch. It is innocent, family fun, and that is what the season demands actually.
7/10

title: Jumanji: The Very Entertaining Video Game Adventure
text: Four very different teenagers are sucked into a video game and transported to the world of Jumanji. Each equipped with an unique set of skills but also weaknesses, they must find a way to finish the game before remaining out of lives in order to go back to their own world.It's a movie which follows about the same concept as the original flick, but also improving it in terms of visual effects. The four new characters are very likeable and funny, playing their part very well in the adventure that follows. Their evolution as teenagers and their relationship with one another is also presented in detail, presenting how each is able to overcome his condition with the help of the others. Their part is the most important, very well played by the actors, contributing decisively to the outcome. Using plenty of references to video games, this movie manages to create a very entertaining atmosphere in which the action can take part. Speaking of which, we have plenty of it, exaggerated of course as they are part of a video game, but still very enjoyable.The plot isn't much as far as the game is concerned, but it is good enough to keep it all together and make it a very good all-rounder. It's not predictable or linear, even having a mystery to be guessed, but it's not breath-taking either. It excels though through dialog, character complexity and development, making it very good in this department. The visual effects however are top notch. It truly is a delight for the eyes to see all the action sequences and all other events which are made possible using CGI.It's a movie which I truly enjoyed. It manages to create a good time for its viewers, while having some great actors who play their characters with style. It's not spectacular in terms of story but it makes up through action, suspense, CGI and even a bit of drama. A very good watch overall.

title: Jumaji Reboot/Sequel

title: Packed full of stereotypes and paint by numbers script
text: We're living in a era of directors and studio execs who saw films twenty years ago and are now in the positions to remake them with their own spin. If you're going to base a film on a classic, then don't just cherry pick the bits you like and throw the rest away!The clever bit about the original - and Chris Van Allsburgs other board game based film; Zathura - was that the action took place in the real world, and how the game would interact with the players actual lives; stampede down main street, big game hunter chasing you, monsoon in the hall. Here, as technology has evolved, so the action takes place inside a computer, yet the game play itself seems to have devolved as the graphics have improved. The NPC's (Non-Player Characters) are supposedly just programmed to interact with the players in a certain way, no matter what they do. The evil game hunter Van Pelt of the original film has been replaced with a two dimensional Professor Russell Van Pelt, who has been given so much power in the game, it would seem unlikely they could survive if he had the same intelligence as his namesake.It's lucky then that the film is more about the relationships between the main characters than actual peril. Alex Wolff/Dwayne Johnson is Spencer, a stereotypical nerd, who plays video games, is awkward around people and rarely gets into trouble. Ser'Darius Blain/Kevin Hart is Fridge; six foot tall footballer, who needs his friend - despite having been pushing him away - of seven years to do his homework so he can keep on playing. Morgan Turner/Karen Gillan is Martha; a smart but shy wallflower with a self image issue. And Madison Iseman/Jack Black is Bethany; a socially obsessed, shallow girl, who can't live without her phone. And in the game, they basically have to face their insecurities; the nerd becomes confident (and strong), the jock becomes smart (and weak), the wall flower becomes an extrovert and the popular girl becomes Jack Black!This last one is a role Black was born to play; a woman trapped in a mans body. Able to play it as effeminately as he wants, make lots of penis jokes and be self-deprecating about his appearance. You knew that as soon as Bethany was out the game she'd make a comment about how glad she was to be in her body.Just like Fridge moans about being the diminutive Hart, Spencer admiring his muscles and Martha questioning her wardrobe choices. All things you'd question if you found yourself in a polar opposite situation and had to adapt.The CGI and film locations are - as expected in the modern era - great, though this seems wrong, given the rudimentary level of the NPC's. They could have had something badly rendered or other throwback to the vintage of the game.It's a good premise, with a strong take away message for the kids, just wish they'd played with the video game premise a little bit more.

title: Good but cliché as hell

title: Wow, didn't see that coming.
text: I finally went ahead and saw Jumanji in theaters. I hadn't planned on watching it as it looked ridiculous, but I must say it was actually fun. The wife and I had a blast watching the movie.Following in the footsteps of the original Jumanji, a group of teenagers get stuck in the Jumanji world after playing the game. This time around to add a modern spin they get stuck in a video game world with multiple lives and all. The humor of the movie, while by no means smart was a lot of fun. It did throw a round some juvenile sex jokes and a repetition of a few comedy tropes but otherwise I found myself laughing quite a bit. They did a good job utilizing the video game concept to incorporate character skills and to add more humor with the concept of dying frequently. Without spoiling anything one of the funniest scenes involves a character's weakness to cake and explosions. Utterly ridiculous but fun.Acting wise the movie isn't going to win any awards, but I thoroughly enjoyed the character interactions. Who doesn't love The Rock, Kevin Hart, and Jack Black. All three had great back-and-forth interactions with each other.The movie was a nice mix of comedy, action, an over-the-top ridiculous. It Is by no means a smart movie, and at times a bit too juvenile. Assuming you're able to turn off your thinking caps when viewing it is a fun ride. A 7.5 out of 10.

title: Very Fun
text: This movie has an amazing cast which makes for an amazing movie. I really enjoyed the plot of the movie and how they modernized the Jumanji game as I think it works really well. Add to that there is so many laugh out loud moments that makes for a solid entry in the Jumanji universe.

title: Fun, exciting, and hilarious

This movie is definitely inspired by the original but it's a completely new, modern adventure! I loved every second and thought it was great. Yes are there cliche moments? Sure, but it was fun nonetheless. Jack Black, The Rock, Kevin Hart?! Hilarious.

title: Family Fun
text: This was a movie that provided a good modern twist on what was childhood favorite of many. Few time do these reincarnation deliver but this film didn't hurt the past film by taking a new approach. The kids outside of the game felt generic and replaceable but the in game characters were very enjoyable to watch. There were moments of cheese through this film but the film new what it was trying to do so it wasn't painful to deal with. I personally approached this film with low expectations but found myself buying it once i had watched it.

title: Robin Williams will be turning in his grave!

title: Good, but not great

title: Better than anticipated, refreshing take on an exsisting IP
text: Went in with no expectations, thinking this will be yet another cash-in remake but was happy to be wrong. A refreshing take on an enjoyable childhood movie. Nothing spectacular about his movie but it was a fun watch with a solid cast that have a better chemistry than expected. It doesn't take itself to seriously but that's the kind of movie it's meant to be.Kevin Hart usually puts me off anything but they even managed to use his style appropriately in this movie and I almost found him enjoyable.

title: So funny you want to watch it again
text: This film had me laughing so much I had to watch it again and again and laughed out loud every time. They just got everything (almost) right, I say almost because they really needed to give us more animals in daylight rather than the watch closely or you'll miss them in the dark animal scenes

title: Fun, but hardly groundbreaking
text: It seems like every Dwayne Johnson movie contractually requires him to be in a jungle at some point. So I guess he was destined to star in the Jumanji remake.I admit this movie was generally enjoyable, but it remains superficial and predictable. Four teenagers get sucked into a game and have to do some kind of dangerous mission - a bit of a twist from the original Robin Williams movie, which I enjoyed a lot as a kid.Part of the problem is that we care more about the stars inside the game who are more famous and better actors than the teens in the real world. It's mildly amusing at first to see the teens react to their new bodies, but we quickly forget their original personalities. Jack Black is so good at acting feminine that I no longer found it funny and just accepted him as a "hot girl" in Jack Black's body.The dynamic of being in a video game with weird rules, like multiple lives, could have been explored more. There are some clever ideas but ultimately the movie falls back onto familiar cliches.Some of the action is pretty cool, but a lot of it is CGI and never feels quite real. Maybe that fits the plot, but it does mean it's less thrilling than if they did more stunts.All 4 main actors are good but the material doesn't really stretch them. It's nice to see Karen Gillan when she isn't blue and half metal. Kevin Hart is funny but only really has one note to play in this movie.Comedy action movies like this need a heart to transcend being average and forgettable. Jumanji doesn't pull that off. In fact, the values are questionable. Maybe they wanted to show that looks and status aren't everything, but the movie actually seems to reinforce that - The Rock is the hero because he's the biggest and Gillan uses her hotness to distract enemies.They simply become the cliches of the main characters rather than having their personalities shine through. It trivialises intelligence and personal achievement, as if looks and strength are just categories to be lucky enough to be born with, rather than things you can develop.Anyway, it was an okay diversion compared to most movies. But it missed the opportunity to be something special.

title: Beating it's drums, Jumanji: Welcome to the Jungle rolls into a new decade with a true video game story thats entertaining
text: Roll the dice. Say the poem. Run from the animal. Repeat. This is exactly the plot from the 1995 family fantasy Jumanji. On the one hand its simple, but on the other, it makes for a fast paced concept, that's ironically slower then you'd imagine. But surrounding it, is a story about facing your fears, growing up, and finishing something you started. Jumanji was one of my favorites as a child...and still is as an adult. A lot of that steams from Robin William's performance, which is more subtle then usual, and that the movie is genuinely scary. I even remember reading critical reviews that complained on how scary Jumanji was for children, but I think adults underestimate just how much children can take. So when it was announced that a sequel was being made, that generated a lot of responses, including how Robin Williams death makes continuing the story unnecessary. There is truth to that, and I'd be lying if I wasn't a skeptic. It changed when I found out that the characters were going into the game. Believe it or not, this is partially the plot for the Jumanji animated series from the nineties (which is pretty good if you can find it). So let's see if Jumanji: Welcome to the Jungle is just as entertaining. In the modern era, a group of high school kids are given detention. We have a hyprocondriac nerd Spencer (played by Alex Wolff), a sports jock footballer Anthony "Fridge"(played by Ser'Darius Blain), a self centered Instagram star Bethany (played by Madison Iseman) and the shy bookworm Martha (played by Morgan Turner). While working, the kids find an old game console (think Nintendo 64) along with a playable game Jumanji. When they decide to play, they all select the chareters they want, and they get sucked into the game.Waking up in a jungle, the kids find they have changed into their chosen characters. Spencer is now Dr. Smolder Bravestone (played by Dwayne Johnson), Anthony is a zoologist Franklin "Mouse" (played by Kevin Hart), Martha is now a commando Ruby Roundhouse (played by Karen Gillan), and Bethany is Professor Sheldon (played by Jack Black). They find that if they want to escape, they have to finish the game of returning a jewel to a mountain. They also find that they have to succumb to the rules of video games...including that if they die three times, it's game over for good.Jumanji: Welcome to the Jungle succeeds in two areas. First, it does feel like an expansion of the world of Jumanji. I like that they show that the animals are just as intimidating...if not more, as they can be possessed. They have villages, airports, and of course, various enemies that are what's you'd expect from video games. Secondly, the movie works as a video game movie. The script makes a lot of jokes when it comes to how they work. Certain characters repeat information; our heroes know things will only get harder towards the end, and they even have certain weaknesses. The best part about this movie isn't even the jungle, but our main actors. That's because since their just video game avatars, guys like Dwayne Johnson and Karen Gillan play against their typical roles. Jack Black gets a lot of laughs as he plays up the idea that he's just a teenage girl on the inside. The only one whose playing himself is Kevin Hart, who doesn't do enough to act like a football player whose now shorter. But regardless, it was fun to see these four make the journey into the jungle, making this a lot like an Indiana Jones movie. The film does fall in certain areas. First of all, I was worried by the intro as I thought it was terrible. We get a scene of the Jumanji board game change itself into a video game just so people would play it (does it even know what video games are?). The high school parts are pretty stock. Just bland geeks, bland jocks, bland teachers, bland lockers, bland everything! It's clear that the storywriters cared more about the jungle sequences then school. I'll also say that parts of the film can be a little too heavy CGI (though it's a big step up from the effects of the original Jumanji), but it lacks a lot of the scares from the old movie that I loved. Oh well.I'll give this seven Jumanji board games out of ten. I'll admit that I was surprised by what I did enjoy out of this. It's different from before, but I'd rather have the sequel take more chances then to do a rehash. Families and fans of the original Jumanji will find plenty to like. Give it a roll and move forward.

title: Best adventure movie
text: Very good movie I liked the location of the jungle too. Dwayne johnson had a great performance. All the actors and actresses have also done a great job.

title: Mind numbingly boring
text:
Mind numbingly boringThis overhyped film does not even remotely match up to the original . There is no narrative tension , no sense of impending danger and the unique interactions with the animals that made the original movie great! 
The intangible sense of magic that the original movie had has completely evaporated into the ether .
I would not bother wasting my time or money on this film . Better to watch the original instead .

title: A Fun Ride For Fans Of The Original
text: It has been over 20 years since the release of the original Jumanji, and quite honestly, I never once thought about ever needing a sequel or revamp of that classic material. I mean, just over ten years ago we saw a great little film in Zathura, so I had my fill of this type of movie. That being said, I never thought I'd be writing a review that tells people to go out and see a film that completely altered what the original film was, but here I am. Jumanji: Welcome to the Jungle is a really fun time at the movies. I won't be comparing it to the original because they both fit their times. Although it's not without its issues, here's why I believe Jumanji: Welcome to the Jungle deserves to be seen in theatres.Being a fan of the original film, I wasn't too keen on the video game aspect that this sequel was injecting into the franchise, but it really worked for me in the context of the story. As the film follows four very generically-stereotyped characters in Spencer, Fridge, Bethany, and Martha, they find themselves stuck in detention after school hours. Coming across an old video game console, they plug it into the television and are sucked into the world of Jumanji. Yes, the question everyone will be asking is how the board game is now a video game, but the movie does a solid job in nodding to the fans about that.After being sucked into the game, they become the avatars they chose. The characters, played by Dwayne Johnson, Jack Black, Kevin Hart, and Karen Gillan are all fantastic here, playing though they're still their outside selves. This aspect is what makes the movie worth it because it allows them to discover new things about themselves, either giving them bravery or realizing life is just fine for them in the outside world. The morals of the story and the climax itself has been seen in thousands of movies throughout the years, but it's all about how a movie is executed these days, and Jumanji: Welcome to the Jungle sucks you in with these characters and provides a very fun adventure, for the most part.This film asks you to pretend that you're actually in a video game with these characters, so repetitive dialogue from secondary characters can become hilarious if you're thinking with that mindset, but also odd for those who are unfamiliar with video games. This brings me to my biggest negative about this movie, because a video game follows either one or multiple characters at the same time, making discoveries along the way. A video game never cuts away to show other plot-lines forming, but this movie does feel like an actual movie at times, cutting away to the villain of the story, who's also the weakest aspect of it as well.The villain, played by Bobby Cannavale (who I'm actually a huge fan of as an actor), is far too over-the-top in this role, which can be funny at times, but it feels out of place when placing random scenes of him and his henchmen throughout the movie. Personally, this portion of the film annoyed me and I couldn't wait to get back to the central characters.In the end, Jumanji: Welcome to the Jungle is fun for fans of the original, providing winks and nods to the first film throughout the movie, as well as providing a fun adventure for all newcomers. From bumping into characters like Alex (Nick Jonas) in order to add some emotional aspects, to having some pretty cool action sequences, to providing humor that both adults and kids can laugh at, I didn't have any glaring issues with the film itself, aside from the incredibly annoying villain subplot. Overall, although not complex in the slightest, Jumanji: Welcome to the Jungle is a fun time at the movies, plain and simple.

title: A perfectly okay movie that's got lots of 'Rock'-n-roll to it.
text: Jumanji: Welcome to the Jungle came out in late 2017 and surprised everyone who came across it: here's a film that's a REBOOT of a 90s-Robin-Williams-film that has Dwayne 'The Rock' Johnson in it, and then this film went on to gross nearly a billion dollars worldwide. I was certainly surprised that Jumanji became such a hit despite all the factors working against it from the start. It managed to out-gross SpiderMan: Homecoming, Justice League and even Wonder Woman. How did it get so big? I think it's all to do with it being a retroactive video game film, that respects and loves video games without BEING a film based off one in the first place.How does Jumanji hold up against the stack of other family-friendly films that have come out during this decade? I reckon it's got some legs in terms of audience appeal and longstanding on home video. It certainly helps with the nostalgia factor people have for the original Jumanji.You want brisk family entertainment that's essentially a family-friendlier Indiana Jones movie but from Sony? Jumanji is that movie. Go ahead; it's good fun all on its own anyway.

title: Family fun
text: Easy to watch movie with Lots of action, bit of humour, a fun movie. And the Rock of course.

title: hated the original..but

title: Surprisingly Worth the watch

There were a few moments, especially leaning hard into the action, that sets this movie quite apart from the original, but still did a pretty good job at telling a good story!The comedy really helped glue this cast together, and had good chemistry together. There were a few things i could say about the cinematography and CGI, but i could look past it to just laugh and enjoy it.7.5/10.

title: A really good comedy, action packed movie!!!

Brilliant acting from some amazing actors and actresses. The film will keep you hooked no doubt so get your popcorn and drink out and enjoy this movie. I absolutely loved it go watch it

title: If in doubt put The Rock in it
text:
Yep it's the return of Jumanji, but after all these years it's not an old fashioned board game, oh no, it's one of them new fangled (by 1996's standards at least) computer ones.
With our cast 'sucked' into the game its down to Amy Pond off of Doctor Who, Jack Black off of Jack Black filums (though a bit camper) and Dwayne Johnson off of the wrestler The Rock to complete the missions and save the day.
It skips along nicely with its various computer game tropes, actors playing against type, knockabout comedy and CGI wild animals.
But alas no Robin Williams5 Phils out of 10PS Expect Jumanji: Return to the Jungle sometime soonPPS Warning this film contains Baby I love Your Way by Big Mountain

title: Laugh out loud funny!
text: I don't generally watch comedies, mostly because I don't tend to find them funny, and I was afraid to watch this because I'm a HUGE fan of the original, but I was extremely pleased with this film. Family friendly and funny for everyone- win-win!

title: Not bad but Not great
text: Your average popcorn movie fun and enjoyable but not a classic...

title: watch the 1995 version, not this one
text: This 2017 version is nowhere compare to the '95 Robin Williams version.

title: Great at what it's trying to be: A comedy.
text: I am not usually into "dumb" B Hollywood films, so I thought I wouldn't enjoy this. I was pleasantly surprised that I was wrong. The strength of this film is precisely that it doesn't take itself seriously, and by doing so removes all need to rate this film based on authenticity and seriousness. It's a funny movie and achieved its objective by making me laugh. The setting of the characters in switched up bodies is hilarious in and of itself, in addition to taking all the "adventure film" tropes and making fun of them. The actors playing the "Jumanji characters" such as The Rock are doing so very well and very comedic about it.This film is a success, unlike many other Hollywood B films which take themselves seriously whilst being bad. This is "bad" but it ends up being funny and good, precisely because it positions itself as a trope.

title: Could Have Been Less Serious
text: It's a fun movie! But there are moments that take itself too seriously which ironically takes away from the movie. Maybe I went in with the wrong expectation that the movie is just going to be a comedy the entire time, but (ironically) I think it would have done better without any serious moments or life lessons. Everything Kevin Hart says is hilarious! The acting in general is great!

title: Welcome back to Jumanji
text: The original 'Jumanji' starring the much missed Robin Williams was so beloved by so many, that I was sceptical about this film when it came out.Thankfully the original is both name checked and the spirit of it very much maintained in this fun sequel, that boasts some big action sequences and laughs along the way.I liked how tongue in cheek it all was also, with all the main cast clearly having the time of their lives.It obviously hit a chord with viewers, as at the time of writing another sequel is about to be released.

title: The most surprisingly good movie in a long time
text: When they announced the new jumanji I was like no why but not was I wrong. I enjoyed almost every minute of this film. The actors shine in there roles and that's what really makes the film. The plot is also good and fast paced. The run town is a little long and some parts drag but overall one of the best action adventures in a long time.

title: Fun to watch for all, but not the same
text: My family went to see this in the theater. I was very excited as the first movie was a big hit for me and I had really enjoyed it. Because of this, I had very high hopes going into the theater.The 4 main characters are sent to detention where they find a videogame changed from a board game that sucks them into it. To get out they have to play the game as a regular video game as their avatars, and not die while doing so. Dwayne Johnson is very well known and has a lot of credit in movies, but in this one he didn't have that click that he always does, perhaps because he was playing a nerdy kid. Kevin Hart's character was funny and entertaining to keep up with, and laughs went all around the theater when he cracked jokes. But Karen Gillan and Jack Black really kept the amusement going. Karen Gillan played another nerdy character but showed extraordinary character devolpment in a hilarious way. Jack Black was a gem as usual. He played a popular teenage girl with classic high school problems, and this really clicked for me.Meanwhile, I had also hoped that there would be some ties back to the first film in 1995, but unfortunately there were not many, only a couple here and there. Something that disappointed my inside kid was the fact that this board game changed into a video game, it didn't seem very realistic and I believe there could have been a lot of success if they had kept it as a board game and been sucked into there the same way Alan Parrish was.Either way, the film was entertaining for what it was and I would recommend for all who enjoy action with a touch of comedy!

title: love it
text: Oh, so much fun, love it, well done! Family movie fun, I really enjoyed it!!! Great cast, great story line, fun and jokes, + adventure, whats not to like!!!

title: My favorite movie of all time
text: It shocks me that's this only has a 6.9!!! This is one of my favorite movies I've ever seen. It is so funny every time I watch it. And even though I've seen it about a 100 times it never gets old. 10/10 would recommend.

title: Just so so
text: The film almost completed the plot of my childhood fantasy. I am eager to be a hero who saves a certain world. I am chased and killed behind me, and I have successfully defeated my opponent with my martial arts. I don't know how to describe the impulse of childhood. I want to fight for my favorite cartoons and my parents, and fight for my favorite games and friends until late at night. I fantasize that I have become an omnipotent hero in the game, and with the help of my friends around me, I will get out of danger again and again.

title: It's good
text: Not a bad movie! Pretty funny and well-made for the most part. Script isn't great, but still a solid movie.

title: Detention Sensation
text: "Smitty tossed me the keys to the storeroom. 'Jake, find some whiskey, will you,' he said, and when I came back with Jack Daniel's and shot glasses and started to pour, Grandpa pulled over another stool. 'Make room, men,' he said. 'This might as well be the night.'"Some stories open with an initiation rite-as here did Frank Baldwin, *Jake & Mimi* (New York: Little, Brown & Co., 2002, 161.) In "Jumanji: Welcome to the Jungle" the 1996 night goes to teenage beachcomber Alex (Nick Jonas) after discovering a strange board game in the sand and disappearing when he plays it."'Nobody misses the war, boy,' he said. 'You understand?' I nodded. ... Every glass of beer was your last. Every letter home. So you got drunk any chance you could. And when you wrote, you made your words count. ... It isn't the war you miss. It's the spirit of those days. Some of us, who got lucky and lived through it, learned how to live. Like we'd be gone tomorrow. Because a lot of us were.' He looked at me. 'You got me, boy?' I nodded. 'Okay, then,' he said gently. ... 'Find something that gives you that charge, Jake. That fires your blood.'" (Ibid., 164.)Four students at Brantford High School, Spencer the nerd, Fridge the jock, Bethany the fox, and Martha the wallflower, are given detention and admonished to, "Think about who you are at this moment of time and who you want to be." Getting bored with their assigned task, they pick up the board game Jumanji and start playing its electronic version.The word *jumanji* can be rearranged thus: break it in two to get Juman-ji. Migrate the 'm' in the middle to the end thus: Juan-Jim. Juan has an alter ego Jim. Each player will discover himself in a game avatar unlike his real life persona. Jumanji having a funny time line, and Alex having a twenty year jump on the others, turns it into a metaphor for living as their adult selves to come, or at least to think about it. As often happens upon graduation the nerd suddenly finds himself in a strong position career-wise, while the football jock's a has-been, to become somebody's lackey. However, in Fridge's case he discovers his calling (zoology), not history that was never his forte. Bethany who was a total manipulator of men now experiences life in a male body, with all its excitable equipment. She'll learn the value of friendship. Martha has game strengths involving martial arts and dancing, good disciplines to develop one's self confidence that was all this babe-in-the-making needed.The game portion of "Jumanji" borrows heavily in its graphics from Daniel 2 in the Bible. There was "a great image... and the form thereof was terrible" (31). There was a powerful king, "the beasts of the field and the fowls of the heaven ... given into thine hand" (38). In Daniel "a stone was cut out without hands" (34) which will eventually smite the image; in "Jumanji" a jewel was plucked by hand out of the image's eye socket, which needs to be replaced. The image in Daniel does the same disappearing act as do the Jumanji players when they're transformed: "like the chaff of the summer threshingfloors; and the wind carried them away, that no place was found for them" (35). The story in Daniel 2 represented a great prophesy, but in Jumanji it's just a matter of thinking through life decisions when on the cusp of adulthood. Daniel and his three friends (17) had to interpret the king's dream in order to get themselves out of their "detention" unscathed.The story seemed to me pretty juvenile, but then that was the intended audience. The CGI was none too subtle. The tom-toms work well if there's lots of bass in the sound system. The black mamba snake was more realistic in "Kill Bill" than in this movie. Spencer comes out with the occasional Yiddishism ("Oy veh!") Jack Black was adorable playing a female in a male body. Dwayne Johnson struggles to play against type. The rest of the acting was okay; they weren't challenging parts.There are two serpentine lip-action scenes you'll likely want to forget--if you can--of the I've-never-done-this-before variety. Good close-ups if you can force your eyes to remain open.It was based a children's book. It's good kiddy fun.

title: A fun remake
text: I usually hate remakes and if I am honest, I wasn't the biggest fan of the Robin Williams original when it came out. This version takes a more modern twist and has the kids in a video game instead of the board game. The foursome is a typical Breakfast Club like group of a jock, a nerd, a beauty queen and a social outcast that doesn't realize that she's pretty all in for a detention. Their job on detention is to clean up a storage room in the basement of the school. They soon stumble over an old video game system and all 4 get sucked into the game.Hilarity ensues as they all end up as opposite characters in the game than the really are. The nerd becomes The Rock, the jock ends up being 5 ft nothing Kevin Hart, the beauty queen is Jack Black and the social outcast a hot Lara Croft type character in skimpy clothing. They have to work together to make it out of the game and back home. Lots of laughs along the way in this very entertaining film

title: This is what entertainment is!
text: If you want a film with many genuinely funny comedy moments, mucho action - and very little to think about - then Jumanji Welcome to the Jungle is for you!The premise is a la "Tron" - players sucked into an alternate "game world" with levels and quests to boot. The action is riddled with well-placed comedy and I did actually find myself laughing out loud. I also found myself sometimes uttering the next line in a very formulaic presentation ("...it's game over, man..")A fun family action film with a bit of everything. The (comedy) acting is top notch, the action, pace and storyline is very predictable - and it is very, very watchable!

title: Funny and lighthearted
text: Different and more comical than the original. The acting was good and enjoyable to watch. Fun movie if you are in the mood for a lighthearted comedy.

title: This is a good movie.. you'll laugh out loud
text:
It's one of those movies you can watch more than once & like it more. So funny ..the cast is fantastic together ..👌😆
Kevin Hart - hilarious & the Rock & Jack Black ..all perfect in their characters in jumanji land. Love to laugh. This is one of my favs. Was on FX tonight..my 3rd time to watch it. U will LOL. Not a stupid or slap stick funny.. great story & acting ! action packed & for all ages. 👍 Pam.

title: Great family fun, enjoyed it more than the original
text: I loved the original but this modern version is more up to date with today's humour and is enjoyable for all ages. A great mix of comedy, action and adventure. It's not going to keep you on the edge of your seat or set your Friday/Saturday night in fire with Oscar wining performances but you'll enjoy it all the same.

title: Funniest movie I've seen in a long time!
text: I was hesitant to watch this as it seemed to have been overly advertised and just got sick of hearing about it and I've also never been a huge fan of Jack Black, but he has instantly turned me into a fan after watching this! Don't doubt me when I say this movie is worth the 2 hours and the money spent. It is nothing like the original, so don't expect that. But I will say I like it better than the original, which is hard to do these days. Jack Black nailed his character of a teenage, social-media-driven girl and had me laughing with almost every word he spoke. The rest of the cast added their humour as well which just made it an amazingly funny movie overall. It's not one that is so focused on the plot as much as it is just being plain funny, which is alright with me and great for anyone looking for a good laugh.

title: After 45 minutes I had to stop. Boring, cringey and uninspired
text: For a person that watched several times the original Jumanji movie, I found this production an insult. Characters are really annoying and completely cliché. There is the strong guy, the nerd, the hot girl and the wannabe funny guy. I don't understand why ruining an old classic tha made dream when I was a child, rebooting the franchise more than 20 years later.I cannot judge the story, as I did not finish to watch, but the movie does not hook me up. This is just another case of Hollywood trying hard to squeeze an amazing 90s franchise, just to earn as much money as possible. I will try to finish the movie, but this will be painful.

title: One line and a lot of sarcasm review
text: Who knew that all you needed to make a contemporary reboot of a successful 90s property was to have a script with a good structure, a plot that makes fantastical sense and a few decent jokes. Perhaps someone should tell everyone else.

title: Surprisingly funny.
text: I accidentally encountered this movie on a wet morning when there was nothing else really showing at the multiplex and I had decided to go to something, no matter what. And I did not expect much of it but I was very pleasantly surprised. It was funny and the story skipped along at a very nice pace and there was some depth to the movie. It does more than you expect and that is rare these days.

title: funny
text:
I remember seeing the first one way back and the mark it left on me. You know when you hear the Jumanji drums the chills you get.. you know what Im talkin bout. This one aint that good for me but it sure makes you laugh. I like Dwayne and Hart workin together.
Worth watching I enjoyed it!

title: Love it
text: This film is brilliant. Completely wasn't what I expected, the characters that they play when they get sucked into the game are such a surprise and then the way they play them is brilliant. Jack Black and Dwaye are absolutely fantastic in playing their roles. It's an exciting film, some funny bits and all in all, a film I'll definitely watch again. 🙂

title: Welcome to the Jungle!
text: I wasn't sure how I would feel about this movie. I noticed positive critic and audience reviews so I decided to see it in theaters on New Year's Day. Having loved the original Jumanji I wasn't sure how I felt about it being transformed into a video game, and having the main characters become avatars. However once the movie got going the premise really worked.Jack Black and Kevin Hart really shined in their portrayal of the most popular girl in school and "Fridge" the football star respectively. I think it took a lot of work and talent for the actors to nail a role of acting as a high-schooler, acting like a video game character in their body.

title: Friend suggested, watched, laughed, cried (I'm soppy) and laughed some more
text: Not having watched Jumanji since the Robin Williams one when it first came out, I didn't know what to expect. My lovely friend said that there were avatars and boy, there were avatars!The kid actors were great, however seeing the Rock with his eyebrow move made me laugh. Jack Black playing a girl in his body - hilarious, especially going to the loo! Kevin Hart as the slow, shouldn't eat cake valet, playing the height card didn't get old. And Karen Gillan trying to flirt looked like me when I tried!And I totally forgot about the metal head in the beginning so that was a good wrap up. Nick Jonas was another good actor. And Colin Hanks at the end? I cried when he said "we named her after the girl that saved my life". Yes, I'm soppy.It's not going to win Oscars for acting and Robin Williams is probably laughing rather than turning wherever he is.Give it a watch. You never know. You may find a funny bone where you least expect it.

title: My lovely family movie Jumanji replace by a tomb raider for babies

The old Jumanji is too good, this one is a a random movie with thetsame title to attract audience. This teach nothing beside the strenght matters the most. All the roles are stereotyped.

title: A good change from the original!
text: The original Jumanji was a fun movie, and Robin Williams was the best special effect in it. I remember enjoying it, but the computer graphic animals needed a lot of work. That has been improved a lot for this movie, but better yet is the fun/diverse cast! Of course it should be updated to be a video game, and I'm sure the stars had a lot of fun making this movie. The Rock and Kevin Hart are fun, and Karen Gillan is great, but Jack Black is the one who steals the show here. Fun for kids and adults!

title: (Dumb) fun that makes ridiculous movies enjoyable
text: Four teenagers are sucked into a mysterious video game that transports them to a jungle where they are physically transformed into the avatars they chose...The script is very character driven and Dwayne Johnson, Jack Black, Kevin Hart, and Karen Gillan are all perfectly cast. Movie doesn't attempt to bring anything new to the table, nor does it need to. It exists just for fun and good time and on those counts, it succeeds. It is the perfect family comedy for the holidays, so don't watch it by yourself.7/10

title: Had a blast
text: I'll keep this one short and sweet. If you're looking for some laughs this holiday season, Jumanji is a must see. The casting was a hit: Hart and Johnson carry over their chemistry from Central Intelligence and they are great together on screen. Jack Black played his role perfectly and Karen Gillan stole the show. She is extremely talented and gorgeous. Gillan was a perfect fit to play ruby roundhouse. 'I was a huge fan of the original and I liked that they chose a different route for this movie. The story felt unique and less predictable. It had some issues, but as a comedy, it is a great movie to see with friends or family and share some laughs. I would see it again. 7/10

title: Welcome To Jumanji!
Return to the jungle one more time...
text: Granted, initially I had somewhat dreaded to sit down and watch "Jumanji: Welcome to the Jungle" after having heard nothing but bad reviews and heard bad talks about this movie. And let's be honest, the original "Jumanji" movie with Robin Williams was indeed a classic in its own right.But still, I went to watch this sequel with my wife, and it turned out that it was actually a blast of an entertaining movie, and they captured the essence of the old movie while actually managing to upgrade the formula to a more up-to-date recipe.Lots of action and fast-paced adventure in the movie, and it is mixed up with a pinch of comedy and witty characters, so what's not to like?The CGI effects in the movie were quite nice and used well. Which essentially made the movie not overly reliant on being a CGI special effects galore.I was initially a bit concerned about having Dwayne Johnson and Jack Black in a movie such as this, but they actually carried the movie quite nicely.If you enjoyed the original "Jumanji" movie then you definitely should take the time to watch "Jumanji: Welcome to the Jungle".

title: Jumanji with a facelift
text: Jumanji got a update, far from the original which we all know is untouchable. This is lighthearted, humorous and modern . Not a bad watch at all...

title: I LOVED IT
text: For me this was one of those films where you are watching it and thinking "I could stay in this moment forever" and wishing that it the movie wouldn't end. It was so much more fun than I imagined it could be. The humour was brilliant and the acting was spot on and you never forgot that the adult faces you know so well are actually the teenagers that started the film, because they play them so well!Also I loved the little details such as in-game characters repeating their lines as it makes you feel like you are a kid again playing a video game as well as watching a great movie. The original was a classic and in my opinion this film took it to the next level with the use of new technology, imagination, a different angle, great writing and as I mentioned, brilliant acting.

title: Pretty routine and mostly a bore.
text: 'JUMANJI: WELCOME TO THE JUNGLE': Three Stars (Out of Five)A standalone sequel to 1995's hit family adventure 'JUMANJI'. This reboot has four teenagers being transported into the video game world of Jumanji, and they must beat the game (playing as the game characters they chose) in order to escape it. The film stars Dwayne Johnson, Kevin Hart, Jack Black, Karen Gillan, Nick Jonas and Bobby Cannavale. It was directed by Jake Kasdan, and it was written by Kasdan, Chris McKenna, Erik Sommers, Scott Rosenberg and Jeff Pinkner. The Box Office hopeful has received mostly positive reviews from critics, but I found it to be pretty routine and mostly a bore. Four teenagers are put into detention together, and assigned to cleanup the basement of their school. While doing so, they find a video game called Jumanji, and decide to play it. The teens are then transported into the game, and become the characters they picked to play. They soon learn that in order to escape the game, and return home, they have to beat it.The film is mildly amusing, because of it's cast primarily, but all of the lead actors can do so much better than this (and I wish The Rock would stop doing silly kids movies like this too, and do more serious action flicks instead). Other than the cast though, there's little to no redeeming qualities in the whole movie, and it's mostly just a bore. It should entertain kids at least though, and it could be a decent family flick to see for Christmas (there's still much better out there though).

title: Trash
text: This may actually be the worst movie of 2017, and thats hard to do considering transformers was so bad I left halfway through the moive.

title: it's not the movie I've been waiting for !!!
text: A simple movie ,a simple logical theme , and there was nothing impressive about it.

title: Surprisingly Entertaining!!
text: Jumanji: Welcome to the Jungle is a fantasy adventure comedy film directed by Jake Kasdan. The film stars Dwayne Johnson, Jack Black, Kevin Hart, Karen Gillan, Nick Jonas and Bobby Cannavale.When four students gets trapped into jungle while playing video game as their game avatars. To return to the real world, they must finish the game.I wasn't having much hope from this film but the film was a good adventure comedy film and is backed by some great adventures scenes.The plot of the film has been adjusted as per the current generation and is been transformed into video game from board game and is been executed nicely.Acting in the film is decent as there is never much scope in action adventure films, but I would like to give an applause to Kevin Hart and Jack Black who were superbly comical.Screenplay of the film is fast paced and will keep you engaged and entertained, climax of the film could've been fine tuned and a little more detail should've been given to the character of Bobby Cannavale. The ending of the film gets too traditional and predictable.Overall and surprisingly entertaining film and will be a good watch on a lazy Sunday afternoon.

title: Jumanji: Welcome to the Jungle
text: Jumanji is just fun. Nothing more, nothing less. If you're able to just live in that world and not pick and poke at things, it's a great time. Fun action, great acting and laugh out loud funny at times even on a second watch.But, it doesn't take a ton of time to flesh out the universe and, much like the characters, we're simply thrown into the middle of it. This makes it pretty easy to find problems but it's still fun.

title: One of the few standalone sequels that is better than the original!
text: Okay, so first off, before anyone says anything, I just want to clarify something: I do like the original Jumanji. The story, the action/adventure, the visual effects and of course, Robin Williams is what made that one a classic and it always will be.Now, as for Welcome to the Jungle: the premise is about four high schoolers who get sucked into the world of Jumanji (much like how Alan Parish did in the first one) and become avatars within the game. As a team and using their avatars' traits/abilities, they have to work together and play through the game in order to complete the game's mission and return to the real world. After seeing this, I was pleasantly surprised at how good this turned out to be. To be honest, I was not expecting it to be all that good, but have to admit, it was quite enjoyable and in quite a few cases, an improvement over its original source material.First off, I think the premise was pretty cool. Instead of the board game premise, having the game be a videogame is a little more interesting and a little more up to date. Plus, it adds more features to the game that the regular board game did not have (i.e. When a avatar dies, they only lose a life and get revived, and the avatars have traits/abilities is pretty cool too). Also, having all the main characters, instead of just one, get sucked into the game and being an avatar within the game is pretty cool too and makes the storyline more interesting as well, as they have to learn to adapt to their character. Lastly, there were some pretty cool twists that you didn't really see coming and made the plot more interesting than the original as well.Secondly, the humor was pretty good and hilarious as well. Yes, the original had its humorous moments (especially with Robin Williams), but here, it was a little more present and made the movie more enjoyable. Dwayne Johnson and Kevin Hart are obviously great as their characters' avatars as they always are, especially when it came to them bashing each other (both verbally and physically!), but Jack Black was probably the biggest standout of them all. Having him pretend to be a spoiled teenage girl whose avatar is an older man in the game itself was a genius move. I swear, I never laughed so hard at Black in a while for that goofy performance and personally, I think this role is what made him funny in live action roles again (he's great in the Kung Fu Panda movies, but those are voiceover roles, and he hasn't been in a good live action role in a while, in my opinion). Also, Karen Gillan was pretty good too playing the awkward character of the group and kudos to her for giving comedy a try. Nick Jonas was pretty funny too, especially when his character made some old fashion jokes (that's explained in the movie). So definitely, I thought the humor was better in Welcome to the Jungle than the original, though that was probably intentional as the first movie was meant to be more of a drama.Also, the action/adventure aspect was done pretty well too. Having more characters and more battles is what made this movie more exciting and intense. Sure, there were not as many animal encounters as the original and there were more human encounters, but still, when the avatars encountered any predators, it was pretty cool and done well. Plus, having it all take place inside the game is what I think allowed for more battles, rather than in the real world, and works out better. Additionally, the villain (played by Bobby Cannavale) is pretty cool too and to be honest, a bit more interesting and sinister than Van Pelt, as he does not just shoot a gun all the time!Lastly, I like the fact that this was more light-hearted than the original as well. Kinda going back to what I mentioned earlier, this one is more of a comedy rather than a drama and that works out perfectly here. This is also where I have a bit of a qualm with the original: the drama made it a little gloomy. Yes, Robin Williams does add humor and lighten the mood of that, but some moments are just kind of depressing, dark, or too intense (i.e. Alan's bad relationship with his father, Judy and Peter's parents being dead from accident, Peter nearly getting crushed by an elephant and nearly swallowed whole by an alligator, and Van Pelt shooting at Alan recklessly and nearly shooting others). Here, with Welcome to the Jungle, I personally thought the writers/producers did a great job of making this more family friendly and more enjoyable and already having a light-hearted tone that makes everyone feel comfortable and engaged in the story/adventure.I could go over more details, but those were the main points that I wanted to cover about why I liked about Welcome to the Jungle. I wouldn't say it's a masterpiece per say, but it's still quite enjoyable and exciting and worth a watch. Now, I still do like the original Jumanji for sure, but Jumanji: Welcome to the Jungle is definitely one of those rare standalone sequels that works and is an improvement over the original source and if you have not seen the movie yet after all these years, I recommend you watch it and you will more than likely enjoy yourselves.P. S. - The tribute that Welcome to the Jungle does for Robin Williams was a nice touch and shows some good respect for the original movie.

title: Wouldn't we all wanna escape in a game...
text: I'm a fan of the the original movie with Robin Williams. So this movie style makes sense that it comes out of a home arcade game.The blend of charters are good and the humor and banter from the characters played by Dwayne Johnson and Kevin Hart ALMOST at times overshadow Jack Black and others performance. Then again Dwayne and Kevin have that comedic relationship in real Life too.Enjoyable movie to watch.

title: Unexpectedly awesome
text: This movie hits the mark perfectly for what it is aiming to do 110%. Possibly it's because I had low expectations, it's also possible that this film doesn't try to be something it's not. For pure entertainment, this is a classic. There were moments I even literally laughed out loud. Call it corny or cheesy, but don't give it a low rating. Go into the jungle.

title: Coll Cast
text:
Very cool cast. I liked the harmony of The Rock, Kevin Hart Jack Black and Karen Gillian and Jonas
Looking Forward for a sequel

title: Great movie!
text: I thought this was an awesome movie. Kevin Hart and Jack Black's characters were hilarious!! This had enjoyable action and comedy, and all together very entertaining for me personally. The music was perfect for the scenes and I thought the stunts and effects were cool. Purchased on Amazon so I could watch whenever!

title: More enjoyable than expected!
text:
I was ready to dislike this film from the very outset, but thanks to excellent performances from the "in game" characters, I was drawn in very quickly. 
As a family film it ticks all the boxes it needs to. The humour works on all of the necessary levels and kept the children completely engrossed in the entire adventure. 
A couple of nods to the story of the previous movie keep things on track, although everything happens a little too quickly in the very early scenes.
Even if you think that a cheesey Dwayne Johnson film isn't for you, you'll be surprised. This is exactly the right place for it and his chemistry with Jack Black, Kevin Hart and Karen Gillan brings a great level of comedy to our screen.

title: What, again?
text: I like Jack Black but he's running his niche character a little thin. He made King Kong (2005) bearable, and was perfect in Tropic Thunder, and I liked the semi-serious turn in The Holiday. Here like in most of his films, he helps with the comic turns but in an usual way that almost makes this his movie. Kevin Hart plays Kevin Hart. The Rock likewise plays the Rock. In this turn the game is amped up to being a video game but you know the drill. It's a pretty much mindless romp that I would have waited to see on HBO or Netflix but that a friend had passes. I guess I am tired of CGI and loud booms and plotless films. I suspect if you are under thirty you will enjoy this and have some laughs but the studios are really pushing Jumanji to the breaking point but I'm sure they will squeeze another film out of this franchise depending on the profits. I am beginning to wish Hollywood would start on the road to bankruptcy already with the endless repetitions.

title: "JUMANJI: WELCOME TO THE JUNGLE" - MY REVIEW
text:
Jumanji: Welcome to the jungle, directed by Jake Kasdan, is an action adventure movie and by no means a direct sequel to the original Jumanji movie released in 1997.
The plot of the film is about four High school teenagers, who while serving detention, comes across the video game and get sucked into it. By doing so they adopt their own 'Avatars' and have to complete the mission given to them to safely reach home.
Director Jake ensures that the audience are entertained throughout the film. The highlights of the movie are it's action, Cinematography and a bunch of good actors. But the film is not without it's share of flaws. The villain's role could have been more tight. That might have made the movie a bit more thrilling. 
Now to the performances. The characters in the game were just enjoyable. Dwayne Johnson works well in the action scenes as well as in the comedy. Kevin Hart was terrific. Kareen Gillan was good especially in the action scenes. Jack Black was sidelined even though he was good in some scenes. The actors in the real world did'nt have much of a role but have made their presence felt. Bobby Cannavale ( Villain), as I mentioned before, could have been provided with a more good role.
All in all Jumaji:Welcome to the jungle, is a fun ride with well excecuted action scenes and witty one liners. Just give it a shot and u won't be dissapointed. 
My rating- 3.5/5

title: Enjoyable but not what I expected!
text: I have seen the Jumanji animated series and loved the '95 movie, from what I know Jumanji has a creepy and frightening setting, it's supposed to make you feel uneasy, but the movie doesn't give that vibe at all it just feels like an another jungle adventure movie.The movie feels a bit predictable, there's a sudden personality change in the characters and some of the scenes just make you cringe, but what it lacks in the story it makes it up with the cast. The chemistry between the cast is amazing, coupled with some good punches it manages to keep the movie afloat.

title: Jumanji
text: Well, it's well-written and I also think that it is appropriate for all the family.

title: A great story with a great action and good acting
text: Oh my gosh, where should I start? This movie was simply awesome. At first, I was very skeptical about it because I knew how good was the first Jumanji movie, however I decided to give it a try and it was absolutely worth it. The story is very well constructed as the audience can quickly understand the plot, without being puzzled or confused which would've been frustrating, of course. From the very beginning you can see the main cause that leads to the entire action, which for me is awesome, because I hate movies who need like an hour in order to get into action and they are boring the audience until then. I appreciated the combination between the entire action and comedy elements which were extremely well introduced and executed by the actors. The dialogues between the characters are cursive, without many "dead moments" and easy to follow. The characters are also very diverse and well-constructed as we have some stereotypes here: the nerd, the hot girl, the tough guy and the shy girl. Exactly this diversity between them helps the characters to form a team and fulfill their objective: rescue Jumanji. What's even more interesting is that this stereotypes are switching between them as soon as the characters are entering the game.What could've been done better about this movie is the CGI which is rather acceptable, than good, but oh well, you cannot have them all in a movie, right? Overall, this movie deserves your time and I recommend it, especially to those of you who are gamers.

title: Fun and funny, but nothing special. Less dark than the original.
text: I can barely remember the original Jumanji, but what I do revolves mostly about the performance of Robin Williams and the somewhat scary parts of it. In the sequel (well, the sequel is Zathura, but you know what I mean) the focus is on the players and less on the "lost guy in the game" while the dark elements are kept to a minimum. The movie has been updated to 2017, with a girl obsessing over her body and smartphone who has to play the game as Jack Black, but her character felt really artificial and the jokes related to her were the most cringe worthy. The other three characters are more timeless: two opposite sex geeks and a football player (the American sort). Together they must overcome the challenges of the game to end the movie. Now, the story you know, so the details of the plot is what is important and I thought they were OK, however I must say that the game itself made little sense, with a pointless villain and a "curse" that affected literally no one. The actors did a good job, their chemistry, as noted by some, worked. Yet it seemed like a waste of Rock in this movie while Karen Gillan made more entertaining just by appearing. Overall a fun movie, but never more than what it was intended to be.I wonder how no one touched on the implications of entering a game then returning into a world that has changed dramatically from what you remembered going in. I mean, just telling Alex to buy stock in Bitcoin would have added a whole new layer to the Jumanji usage :)

title: Great!
text: This is a great reboot of an old classic! I was skeptical of this at first but I LOVED it!

title: Cute
text: The good thing is, this is a remake without being a remake. It makes you feel like you are watching a whole new movie, but it originates from a classic, but does not make you feel like you are just rewatching the same movie from the 90's. I appreciate how they tried to recreate a new perspective.

title: Absoutely wonderful!
text: For Christmas, I received one hundred dollars in PlayStation cards...so I bought some movies. One of them was Jumanji. I can't tell you how much my grandson and I enjoyed this film! It really keeps you on the edge of your seat and special effects are so cool! The acting is great and I loved seeing Jack Black in a movie again...it's been a while. I found nothing wrong in this movie that my 6 year old grandson couldn't watch. It's a movie for all ages and it's great fun to watch I highly recommend it to anyone wanting to see this. Until next time!

title: Will make you laugh
text: Ok it's not a serious film! But the characters are great and I was laughing out loud when I saw it. Will definitely watch it again...love the Rock. You know what you're getting with him. Muscles and merriment! Highly recommend for an easy funny watch

title: wow.. my popcorn was more intertaining than this
text:
The only funny actor in this movie was the avatar of the geeky girl. the writing was pointless, flat. this is a movie written for kids. what passes for humor these days is just sad
A waste of my time and money. I should've trusted my instincts about the trailer and clips to not to set foot in the cinema watching this crap. Unfunny recycled jokes, lame story and kindergarten level villain. Jumanji suppose to be exciting, emotional, funny and a little scary, but this movie failed to achieve none of it. The screenwriters probably wrote the script in the bathroom on toilet paper and forgot to wipe with it their ass. Dwayne Johnson and Kevin Hart are from now on my official kryptonite. Arnold S. had more charisma than both of them together. Even Jack Black who I dig, gave a goosebumps level performance.Robin Williams is probably turning in his grave.

title: Warm hearted entertainment for all the family
text: A silly, warm-hearted, well executed adventure film for all the family. Jumanji is fully aware of what sort of film it is and what it's audience wants and it sticks to that formula unashamedly. But that's why Jumanji is a surprising success. It's got enough old school "Indiana Jones" style capers to appeal to the nostalgics, whilst incorporating plenty of modern gaming references and in-jokes to entertain a new crowd. There isn't a weak link in the cast (Black and Gillan both comedic standouts) and although highly predictable Jumanji even has a credible moral core. I'd happily play it again.

title: Not what I expected, but hilarious
text: I thought the humor was the greatest. Jack Black probably stole the show with his portrayal of a teenage girl. He was so much fun! Of course, it was way off the original movie, but that honestly doesn't bother me when a movie is done well.

title: Funny, Well Written Jungle Story And Humour
text: I Had no idea how i ended up finding this movie, but after watching im surprised that it was good. This should be apropriate enough if you had a kid that is 10 and up, The humour and action is perfect for a movie like this.

title: A fun movie & a real laugh
text: Shamefully when I first watched this movie, at the time I'd never seen the original, so I certainly was not comparing. I just loved this movie so much though, mainly because I found it to be a lot of fun and a really good laugh. Highly recommended!
