title: Jumanji - Welcome to the Jungle Review
text: Jumanji - Welcome to the Jungle is a film directed by Jake Kasdan. I am not particularly a fan of the 1995 film but I would still say that I had a good time watching the film. The announcement of this film quite astonished me and the trailers for the film seemed OK. I was actually surprised as to how much I liked the film.Plot: Spencer, Martha, Bethany and Anthony are all sucked into the video game Jumanji where their only way to survive is to finish the game.Story and direction: Sony is mostly famous for taking something that is famous and turning it so commercial that the profit is earned but the quality is very bad. But this film understands that it has to deliver, quality wise. I wouldn't say the story has groundbreaking elements or things that we haven't seen before, but the film manages to entertain. I liked the way we have troubled characters that are sucked into one situation and their only way out is if they work with one another. Also very nicely incorporated is the video game aspect of Jumanji. WE have a life bar, character strengths and weaknesses, non player characters, exposition that helps us understand what the game is. This entire world of Jumanji seems very much believable (because of it being a video game world). The action sequences were good and nicely done. However, there were one or two places where horrible VFX (or green screen) has been used to execute the action sequences. The score by Henry Jackman also adapts to the situation and adds something refreshing to the film. My other problem with the film is that certain scenes are not explained very properly. They seemed to have just let that go for the sake of it. Performances: Dwayne Johnson is good what he does. Kevin Hart did add his touch of comedy to the film. Karen Gillian's character was different and I liked it. I didn't understand the casting of Nick Jonas since he wasn't acting at all. Jack Black was the surprise package. I know he is good, but in here he is the highlight of the film. Rhys Darby, Rohan Chand and Bobby Cannavale did provide good supporting roles. Even the teenagers in the real world delivered compelling performances.Favorite Scene: It would be the one where Bethany (in Sheldon Oberon's body) teaches Martha (in Ruby Roundhouse's body) how to flirt with someone. I can seriously say that I laughed so hard in the scene because of its awkwardness and absurdity.Verdict: WELCOME TO THE JUNGLE is a good follow-up to the 1995 film. I was highly entertained by the film and had a very good time. I don't know what the sequel in 2019 will consist of as no room was left for a third instalment.I am going with an 8/10.

title: Simply Fun

title: Loved It
text: As someone who grew up watching the Jumanji film with Robin Williams I was worried about the new film and if this would ruin the film that I grew up loving. I was gladly proven wrong! This film is based after Jumanji and is through a video game which is more with the times rather than board games, not only this but it is based around two people who are more nerds/geeks (one male and one female) and two of the popular group (one male and one female). As you see them coming to terms with their new characters and making it so that the popular ones are the more weak characters who aren't as popular and vice versa it made the film something for everyone. The casting for this film was amazing and having such amazing actors who made this film hilarious making me even cry with tears at some points. Not only this but there later on in the film there is a part where there is a mention of Alan who was Robin Williams character in the original film. To me this was a perfect way to honor him and the film franchise by acknowledging this and not trying to make it a remake but just a more modern film which shows where Alan was trapped within the game and why he was so scared about what was inside the game itself. This film is amazing and I couldn't praise it high enough and it is a film that is perfect for the whole family.

title: Jumanji at its best
text: This Jumanji sequel is the best of the entire Jumanji movies from beginning to end, at least so far.The graphics and animations work, the characters work, excellent cinematography, great mix of cast, and most importantly a consistent and steady rise and fall progression of the story make it flow seamlessly and undistracted.The Jumanji movies have come a long way since the awkward story, acting and animation of the original Robin William Jumanji series and the non-jungle versions. Bringing the board game into the video game age was something I was at first skeptical about, but ultimately it worked very well, in addition to casting adults as opposed to a majority children cast.Having two separate generations come together between the 1990's culture meeting 2000's culture was a another brilliant idea.This is a movie I could watch more than once.

title: Jumanji Turns into a New Generation of Games
text: It has been over 20 years since the release of the original Jumanji, and quite honestly, I never once thought about ever needing a sequel or revamp of that classic material. I mean, just over ten years ago we saw a great little film in Zathura, so I had my fill of this type of movie. That being said, I never thought I'd be writing a review that tells people to go out and see a film that completely altered what the original film was, but here I am. Jumanji: Welcome to the Jungle is a really fun time at the movies. I won't be comparing it to the original because they both fit their times. Although it's not without its issues, here's why I believe Jumanji: Welcome to the Jungle deserves to be seen in theatres. Being a fan of the original film, I wasn't too keen on the video game aspect that this sequel was injecting into the franchise, but it really worked for me in the context of the story. As the film follows four very generically-stereotyped characters in Spencer, Fridge, Bethany, and Martha, they find themselves stuck in detention after school hours. Coming across an old video game console, they plug it into the television and are sucked into the world of Jumanji. Yes, the question everyone will be asking is how the board game is now a video game, but the movie does a solid job in nodding to the fans about that. After being sucked into the game, they become the avatars they chose. The characters, played by Dwayne Johnson, Jack Black, Kevin Hart, and Karen Gillan are all fantastic here, playing though they're still their outside selves. This aspect is what makes the movie worth it because it allows them to discover new things about themselves, either giving them bravery or realizing life is just fine for them in the outside world. The morals of the story and the climax itself has been seen in thousands of movies throughout the years, but it's all about how a movie is executed these days, and Jumanji: Welcome to the Jungle sucks you in with these characters and provides a very fun adventure, for the most part. This film asks you to pretend that you're actually in a video game with these characters, so repetitive dialogue from secondary characters can become hilarious if you're thinking with that mindset, but also odd for those who are unfamiliar with video games. This brings me to my biggest negative about this movie, because a video game follows either one or multiple characters at the same time, making discoveries along the way. A video game never cuts away to show other plot-lines forming, but this movie does feel like an actual movie at times, cutting away to the villain of the story, who's also the weakest aspect of it as well. The villain, played by Bobby Cannavale (who I'm actually a huge fan of as an actor), is far too over-the-top in this role, which can be funny at times, but it feels out of place when placing random scenes of him and his henchmen throughout the movie.Personally, this portion of the film annoyed me and I couldn't wait to get back to the central characters. In the end, Jumanji: Welcome to the Jungle is fun for fans of the original, providing winks and nods to the first film throughout the movie, as well as providing a fun adventure for all newcomers. From bumping into characters like Alex (Nick Jonas) in order to add some emotional aspects, to having some pretty cool action sequences, to providing humor that both adults and kids can laugh at, I didn't have any glaring issues with the film itself, aside from the incredibly annoying villain subplot. Overall, although not complex in the slightest, Jumanji: Welcome to the Jungle is a fun time at the movies, plain and simple.

title: Better than the 1995 original
text: Simply put, the sequel is better than the 1995 original. What really makes a huge difference is that the sequel has a consistent emotional tone unlike the more erratic original which waivered between comedy and horror and serious drama. The humor is also more rich in terms of gender bending and the solid comedy derived from the script instead of the singular efforts of Robin Williams in the original. Karen Gillian also deserves some credit for her performance and her ability to capture both her Jumanji character as well as the meek, nerdy high school girl. The only seemingly faint weaknesses come in the form of the overly dramatized motorcycle scene and the rhino scenes which could both been more carefully scripted in a more realistic formula (too many motorcycles and the practical speed of rhinos versus helicopters) and the to be expected but quite poignant moments as well as attempts at coming of age attitudinal changes that in a few places almost came across more superficially brief than genuine. Nevertheless, this sequel succeeds well in this depiction of a video game and tantalizing use of special character powers and game lives. The pacing, the fun irony, the action, the human messages, and the performances all come together in this entertaining and captivating movie.

She acts the hell of the role, she's funny and weird, while she's intense and funny as Nebula for the MCU. Sold!

title: Pleasantly Surprised
text:
JUMANJI: Welcome to the Jungle (2017)
RATING: 3.7/5Well that was a pleasant surprise. Definitely turned out being a lot better than i thought it would. Kevin Hart and The Rock are a good comedy duo, that are probably not going anywhere anytime soon. Jack Black was pretty good, and i actually wish they would have done more with him. Karen Gillen has the potential to be a good comedic actress, if she gets the chance. I remember how good she was on her "Selfie" TV show, so i know she has potential, and it's nice to see it used here to a degree.For those that don't know, i majored in Game Design, so it was really interesting for me to see how this movie played with video game tropes. They did a pretty solid job, especially for a video game with no tutorial or instruction manual. For people that don't play video games, this is a pretty decent introduction into the medium, and what you can expect from video games. It's even interesting how you see the characters use the games rules to their advantage, it's actually used in a clever way. Being that Jumanji is a video game, you also get a generic video game bad guy, which was fine because he wasn't the point of the movie. The whole point of Jumanji is to beat the game and get home, so the villain is really just a tool for the game to throw at you.I think what surprised me the most, was the movie's meta narrative choices. It had something to say about your strengths, weaknesses, team work, life. I think the one that hit home the most was the narrative about making the most of the life you have, considering the characters had 3 lives in the game. Yeah, it was semi obvious about it, but it never dwelled on it long enough for you to get annoyed or roll your eyes either. The message really hit home by the time you got to the end of the movie.I never laughed out loud or anything, but i did get some good laughs here and there, and the overall message was definitely a good one. If you want to have a good time at the movies, this holiday season, Jumanji might be the movie for you.

title: Jack Black Crushed It
text: Jumanji: Welcome to the Jungle is the rare occasion that a reboot/sequel is better than the original. With a stellar cast, engaging plot and unique set pieces, I found myself constantly engaged.What impressed me most about this film was how well the avatars embodied and embraced their real-life counterparts. Jack Black absolutely crushed it as Bethany and made for some of my favorite moments.There were a few cheesy pieces of dialogue and some effects that were a little too video game-esque. However, as a whole this film was a surprise joy and a treat to watch.Additional thought: The later scene in front of the Vreeke house was one of the best moments of the film. It was emotionally charged and reminiscent of the final scene in the original Jumanji (only better!)

title: About what you'd expect, but a bit more complex
text: Just a disclaimer: I haven't seen the original Jumanji, so I am not sure if this changes my opinion. So, anyway, this is about what you'd expect from a Kevin Hart and the Rock movie, good, funny, kinda dumb. It's very funny, but it is simple, and doesn't give much more meaning than what is displayed directly on screen. There are quite a few good jokes that weren't spoiled by any of the trailers. It has more story than Central Intelligence, but not as many jokes. It also has more character development and more complex jokes. I honestly prefer Jumanji to Central Intelligence, merely because it is more complex than other Dwayne Johnson movies. Getting into the nitty-gritty details, the camera angles during the fight scenes are completely awful, with that whiplash-inducing cut every second mentality that seems to be becoming ever more common in Hollywood movies. The acting is good, I mean it has Dwayne Johnson, Kevin Hart and Jack Black, so how bad could it be? The writing is also pretty good as well. There was really only one joke that really grated me, as well as the fact that nothing was explained about the game itself. Being a geek myself it really frustrated me that they didn't go deeper into this anonymous video game console, but at this point I am nitpicking. I don't want to spoil anything, but the way that the game ends makes it very unlikely that there will be a remake, which in my opinion would have been cool to see.

title: Great for OLDER kids
text:
Fair warning to parents who want to take their kids to this film: It is NOT for young children. It is PG-13, not PG. And, boy, does it earn that 13. Although the movie is hilarious, and I thoroughly enjoyed myself, a lot of the dialogue is really crass. There are sexual references and profanity throughout the film. I'd say if you were okay with your kid watching the "Guardians of the Galaxy" movies, it's about that same level, but I still urge you to use your discretion. I think the idea behind this was "This is for the kids who grew up with the 1995 original and are adults now so let's make it "edgy."" So dumb, and so unnecessary. As for the quality of the actual film, I did enjoy it. I was worried that the jokes would get stale, especially since for the most part they are essentially repeated, but they actually got funnier as the film went on. It took the original premise, set it in modern day, and actually had a pretty good message behind it about loving yourself for who you are and making the most of life. So it's a shame this had to be so crass. What were you thinking, Sony? I thought the film was hilarious in the parts that weren't crass and those really worked, so why couldn't the whole film have been like this? It would have actually been better as a PG. Making something more "adult" ironically makes it more "childish." There was a parent at my screening who brought their young child to this film and they left halfway through because she got sick of all the inappropriate dialogue and innuendo. (Which I realize is redundant). This felt like a parody of the original, while also honoring the original, (including a mild 5-second shoutout to Robin Williams' character from the original) and had some good action scenes. It's not only a mild parody of adventure games but also the tropes of the characters from those games. (Invincible hero, smart mouthed comic relief, strong female character). It was clever and I can tell the actors had a lot of fun making it. At points, it even felt like a Guardians of the Galaxy film. So, yeah, great, hilarious movie. Just don't take your young kids to it.
Grade: A- 9/10 4/5 stars

title: Good. But not as good as the Original
text:
Jumanji, starring Robin Williams in the year 1995 was one of our favorite films growing up. The novel concept, brilliant acting & intriguing script made it one of the most entertaining films of the year. People of all ages loved it. Is the new version of the cult favorite as good as the original? 
Jumanji: Welcome To The Jungle starring Dwayne "The Rock" Johnson is a story about four high school students placed in detention together, who discover the five player action player called Jumanji. The writers have smartly included all the stereotypical high school students - the nerd, the football star, the babe & the shy bookworm. Everybody who has been through high school thus has that one character they can relate to. They all end up choosing avatars who are polar opposites to their real life identities. Spencer the nerd, chooses Dr Smolder Bravestone - a 6 ft 5 inches tall archaeologist & explorer. Bethany the pretty & self centred cheer leader becomes Sheldon "Shelly" Oberon (Jack Black)-a cartographer, a cryptographer, an archaeologist . Football Jock Fridge chooses to become Franklin Finbar(Kevin Hart) - a short zoologist & weapons valet. Bookworm Martha Kaply chooses to become Ruby Roundhouse(Karen Gillan) - a commando, martial arts expert & a dance fighter. They all have three lives. If they lose all their three lives in the game, they actually die in the real world. They all have their strengths & weaknesses. They learn from Nigel, an NPC guide that Van Pelt wants to obtain a Jewel - Jaguar's Eye, which gives him power to manipulate all the animals in Jumanji. It is up to to our four heroes & another character Alex Vreeke - who chooses the character of Jefferson McDonough to return the jewel to the jaguar statue & shout "Jumanji". 
The movie kept us entertained throughout & kept us glued to our seats. Some of the situations & dialogues were outright funny. Dwayne Johnson sticks to his strength - action. He has several action packed scenes to showcase his bravado & he doesn't disappoint. Jack Black nails his act of a cheerleader trapped in a obese cartographer's body. Kevin Heart is funny as the short zoologist. His scenes with Dwayne Johnson are hilarious. Karen Gillan is eye candy & plays her part convincingly.
Viewers who haven't seen the original will find the reboot thoroughly entertaining. But those who have seen the original will be a tad disappointed. The anxiety viewers felt every time the characters in the original rolled the dice, could not be replicated in the movie. The board game provided much more fodder for entertainment as compared to the console version. Hence while the board game version became a cult favorite, the new one will be soon forgotten.
We would recommend you to not miss watching the movie at a theatre near you & not miss the 3-D effects. Do take kids along. They will love this one.

title: Rare sequel that improves on the original
text: I recall watching the original movie 3 times at the cinema when it first came out in 1995. It's an enjoyable ride and the late Robin Williams infuses the story with warmth and heart. Trouble is, Jumanji's plot was nothing to write home about. All the players had to do was roll the dice and attempt to survive whatever horrors flew out of the game.Jake Kasdan's sequel is a much smarter and involved effort - the players actually need to interact with the game if they're ever to escape and go home. In this sense, Welcome To The Jungle shares key similarities with Spielberg's Ready Player One. More significantly, both movies resonate with a modern audience who live and breathe interactive media.Kasdan adds multiple layers to this story, most notably in the way he juxtaposes the lead characters with their avatars. You don't get much bigger and stronger than Dwayne Johnson, yet the character isn't really Smolder Bravestone - it's Spencer, the nervy nerd with a host of allergies and a fear of squirrels. Karen Gillan excels as Martha, clearly appalled at having to live in the body of Lara Croft (sorry, Ruby Roundhouse). "Why am I wearing this outfit in a jungle? Tiny, little shorts and a leather halter top. I mean, what is this?"Perhaps best of all is the genius move of having the gorgeous, self-obsessed Bethany (Madison Iseman) wind up in the game as an overweight, middle-aged male professor. Jack Black had a blast playing a narcissistic 16-year old and absolutely nails it.The film is a riot and Kasdan manages to balance the action with plausible character development. Mercifully, Kevin Hart (just about) stays on the right side of that very thin funny/annoying line. The action scenes are extremely well done and the characters are often in genuine peril. A canyon helicopter ride is particularly nail-biting and the solution to numerous life-or-death dilemmas come in surprising ways.If you enjoyed Jumanji, don't expect a glossy retread - Welcome To The Jungle truly ups the game. Go ahead and roll the dice; this one's a winner.

title: Very fun and thrilling!
text: Jumanji: Welcome to the Jungle is directed by Jake Kasdan, written by Chris McKenna and staring Dwayne Johnson, Karen Gillan, Jack Black and Kevin Hart.Story by Chris McKenna, and it's about four high-school kids discover an old video game console with a game they've never heard of--Jumanji--they are immediately drawn into the game's jungle setting, literally becoming the avatars they chose: gamer Spencer becomes a brawny adventurer (Dwayne Johnson); football jock Fridge loses (in his words) "the top two feet of his body" and becomes an Einstein (Kevin Hart); popular girl Bethany becomes a middle-aged male professor (Jack Black); and wallflower Martha becomes a badass warrior (Karen Gillan). What they discover is that you don't just play Jumanji--you must survive it. To beat the game and return to the real world, they'll have to go on the most dangerous adventure of their lives, discover what Alan Parrish left 20 years ago, and change the way they think about themselves--or they'll be stuck in the game forever...I liked this movie so much, it's unique and better than the first Jumanji, but Jumanji: Welcome to the Jungle isn't a sequel, it stands on it's own.Anyways, Jumanji: Welcome to the Jungle is full of action sequences which were very good, very talented performances in the world of Jumanji, but in the real life, the performances were bad, and it takes to another thing I hated about this movie, I didn't see so much of Jumanji or lots of animals as I expected to see. The CGI of the animals wasn't that good anyway. The story is really good, I loved every sequence of this movie, it's like video game but a movie, I loved it! The sense of humor of this movie is really funny, I liked that , but Kevin Hart with Dwayne Johnson scene was so Central Intelligence, I didn't that, but I laughed though.I liked Jumanji: Welcome to the Jungle very much and I'm gonna give it a B+.Thank you, guys as always for reading my review, I hope you liked it, and I welcome all of your comments.

title: Strong performances exceeds expectations
text: Having heard much about this film, knowing somewhat of its history based on the original Jumanji (released in 1995), this remake/sequel delivers more and better than have expected. What makes this film work is the script and overall character performances. Lead by Dwayne the Rock Johnson, Jack Black, Kevin Hart and Karen Gillan, the chemistry among them is the undersell.The action blends in well with the comedy, as it isn't too vulgar and not too silly but with a well balance between clever and some silly gags. It also doesn't completely force itself like many comedies do nowadays. Most of the comedy does come from the characters interactions among themselves as well as the situation they are in.A sequel to this film was inevitable due to the amount of money this movie made at the box, which appears to be coming out towards the end of this year. Now it somewhat feels like a rush and people will of course expect something as great or on par as this film, which is why I think the sequel won't be as good. Simply because what more can they improve on, and how to keep it fresh. Only speculation but hoping for the best for the sequel of course. No doubt it will be a big success (perhaps not as big as this film but none the less it should still be a hit). Highly recommend

title: Ruby Roundhouse: Killer of Men
text: This (notional) sequel is a fun watch and stands on its own; whether one saw the original (board game styled) movie with Robin Williams is mostly irrelevant. Dwayne Johnson, Karen Gillan, Kevin Hart, and Jack Black are all perfectly cast and have excellent chemistry. One likes to think this likeable group had fun making the movie, but who knows really. This movie is fun from beginning to end and is rewatchable on occasion. The ending provides good closure, and the end-credit illustrations are a nice touch, acting as a low-key coda (using thoughtful references to imagery from the film).The character dialogue is a huge part of the fun (and adds to the chemistry). There are many LOL lines; some are quotable. The Rock does an excellent job role-playing the nerd inhabiting his body; similar comments can be made about the other three. All four stars are capable of carrying a film on their own, so getting them together for this production was smart and a big win. Dwayne Johnson is listed as an executive producer, so his casting choice was obviously pre-ordained. How exactly the other actors got onboard is probably something I will track down; there's got to be some behind-the-scenes trivia online.I give this INSPIRED film 7.5 stars for entertainment value (complete with many clever and hilarious details -- see review title) with a half-star bonus for Karen Gillan and her Ruby Roundhouse outfit (OH yeah). That's eight (8) stars total.

title: A lot of great fun
text:
Never seen the original, but I love the sequel!
Four teenagers in detention stumble across a video game called Jumanji and decide to play it. Upon starting the game, they are sucked in and discover that the only way to get back to the real world is by finishing the game.
A brilliantly written, well-executed movie. When I watched this, some of it reminded me of Raiders of the Lost Ark and it turns out that it was directed by the son of the guy who wrote the screenplay for Raiders! And he does an excellent, excellent job.
Dwayne Johnson is so darn hilarious in this movie! He is playing a scared-of-everything, ill-confident, awkward teenager stuck in a muscly action hero/leader avatar and he does it sooo well! The character is so polar opposite to every other role I've seen Johnson in that I wouldn't have believed that Johnson could do it if I didn't watch it for myself. He is utterly convinces you that he really is a skinny awkward teenager stuck in a handsome muscular avatar (no, I don't have a crush of him). The role is both for and against Johnson. I was laughing so much watching Johnson in this role. He's the only one who could do his character as well as he does.
Everyone does their roles really, really well and really fit their characters. It's funny, full of action, and close shaves.
Love it and am looking forward to the sequel.

title: Un unconvincing and not so entertaining sequel
text:
Probably it's because I'm not particularly fond of the original with Robin Williams, but I knew from the first trailer that I wouldn't like this reboot/sequel,
certainly the reviews and the unexpected success at the box office had convinced me to give him a chance, so that in the end I joined the wide audience who decided to go and see it at the cinema, during the holiday season.
Well I must say that the first part was also convincing me of the opposite, with a good start, the pleasant lines, often zany and some of which citationists and referienzal (types of jokes that I prefer), pretty action scenes and functional gags , thanks for the most part to the discreet interpretations of the protagonists.
But all this refers only to a promising first part, let's say the first forty minutes of film, because after them the film begins to collapse like a house of cards on a windy day.
The causes are many but the main ones are a screenplay that with the going of the minutes becomes more and more tired and weak, characters to which you are not attached ever despite the attempts of the actors that between voices, visual expressions over the lines, and frantic and exaggerated stunt, try in every way possible to save the film in vain (apparently for many, however, worked), but at least they make up most of the merits of the film, especially Jack Black.
In addition in the film is missing a real villan, the film tries to characterize two, the island itself with its various challenges, and Van Pelt (interpreted trivially by Bobby Cannavale), but neither is sufficiently developed or exploited as it should , especially the second that ends up being useless to say the least.
Towards the end the film proves to be a continuous repetition of jokes and gags, one similar to the other, but less brilliant, less citationist, less amusing, the same is true for the various sequences of action that follow each other without any connection as if they were simple steps and, if for a video game this is fine, for a film is not so, making it simply not fun, not very engaging but quite boring and repetitive.
Too bad because some good ideas are there but most of them are not developed at all, or superficially developed, so in the end what could be a good comedy action movie that paid homage to the original Jumanji and to the world of videogames in a self-ironic, idiotic (but cleverly) and original way has turned into a flat, tasteless, anonymous and, I repeat, boring Blockbuster.
However, I am glad that most of the audience this new "Jumanji" liked, I hope in a second vision, maybe in Blu Ray and in the original language (here in Italy in the cinema the movies are dubbed in our language), that manages to convince me.

title: Ambitious, but ultimately fell short
text: Before I start this review, I feel I must preface it quickly. I have never seen the original 1995 release (I was only born in 1999) so I can't comment on any links it may share with the 2017 addition. Also, I watched it in a 4D showing, and as a result, I may have missed certain elements due to being tossed around etc. With that aside, I shall proceed. Jumanji: Welcome to the Jungle is an interesting, if seemingly confused film. Directed by Jake Kasdan, the film seems uncertain as to what it wants to be. Upon googling the genre, one can find five listed by the search engine: Action, adventure, comedy, fantasy and Family. Already, that's a handful. Romance subplots are also attempted, in addition to moments which seem to be attempting to invoke horror. Despite it's 12A rating, it seemed determined to squeeze as many curse words as they could, and while there was very little actual blood, the violence was cranked up as far as they dared. You see a man get mauled by a hippopotamus, another erupt into an explosion, a gunshot wound etc. I feel it's rather safe to say it attempted to please everybody. In doing so, it's failed to please me. I would much rather a film focus on a few things and excel, rather than trying to do everything and winding up mediocre at best.Boasting a very respectable 77% on rotten tomatoes, at first glance it may seem that i'm the minority in my low to middling opinions on the film. Upon further examination, however, it seems that many critics were instead rather uninterested by the film. Currently, it's average critic rating is a 6.1. This doesn't mean it's a bad film by any means, but it instead shows how the 'Tomatometer' can occasionally be misleading. Were it rated at a 5.9, I believe the film would no longer be eligible for a fresh rating, let alone the 'certified fresh' it has received.Overall, I feel the main issue was the writing. I feel very little effort was put into the writing, particularly regarding the dialogue. Much of it felt clumsy, and painfully cheesy at times. It was so distracting that at one point my sister, who had seen (and enjoyed) the film at a previous date, leaned across to let me know I might cringe at the next scene. for myself personally, I didn't find it any more painful that the rest of the film. For other viewers, however, it may be an issue.The performances, overall, were actually one of the stronger points of the film. While the actors had to deal with the previously mentioned poor dialogue, many of the actors were able to do their job well. Jack Black, though I found his character infuriating at times, was consistent, and the audience I was with seemed to enjoy his antics. Karen Gillan portrayed a shy teenage girl notably well, and I was even pleasantly surprised by Nick Jonas (yes, I had to google which brother it was). Jonas's character of Alex was even given a mature, bittersweet ending. Without spoiling specifics of the film, his character's end was different to the rest of the team. Unfortunately, it also raised some questions about the other character's conclusions, and the specific rules within which this world operates. Regardless of the confusion, I also found the ending unsatisfying, and feel the film would have benefited by cutting off the last three minutes or so.Many of the CG effects were rather disappointing, that may be attributed to the budget. Hiring a handful of big-name stars presumably took a big chunk from the $100 million or so budget. The animals looked poor at times, and some of the CGI stunts were lacklustre, rather ironically looking more at home in a video game. Additionally, the villain was entirely forgettable. Bobby Cannavale's portrayal wasn't bad, the writing just made him feel almost entirely useless. The plot would have worked just as well if he wasn't present.With this being said, many of the shots were actually quite impressive. The one that stood out to me was quite a simple one. At one point in the film, a row of torches light up through the jungle. Though simple, the contrast between the blazing torches, and the inky blackness of the jungle at night was truly impressive, particularly due to the staggered ignition of the flames. It seemed as though the pathway was carving itself through the trees when the film cut to a wider shot.Overall, I found this film a real mix. Ultimately, out of ten, I feel I have to give it a five. That isn't to say it's a consistent, comfortable five, however. At times, the film sinks to a three. At others, the moments you'd go to see the film for, it raises to perhaps a seven. I'm simply giving what I feel would be an average for the film as a whole. If you're a fan of the cast, I'd imagine you'll enjoy the film; both Dwayne Johnson and Kevin Hart barely seem to be playing characters, and while I don't particularly enjoy them, they have good chemistry and work well off of each other. Obviously, if you're looking for a serious film with a strong moral, this film isn't for you; it ultimately boils down to 'be happy with yourself'. Whether you look like a WWE superstar or not.

title: excellent movie
text: This movie is excellent. Everything works: rhythm, characters, jokes, plot, action, even the messages are good. I was highly entertained. Oh, and it's hilarious!

title: A fun time!
text:
Jumanji is without a doubt one of the best acted movies ever. Everyone shines in their own way. You would think one of the actors/actress would not play the part of the teens that well but boy did they succeed. This movie is hilarious with its constant jokes. I laughed at every joke. The adventure of getting there was also fun. It feels like you're actually playing the video game.
Dwayne Johnson plays the nerdy kid who shines as the leader. Karen Gillan plays as the introverted kid who is awkward but cute. Kevin Hart is the funny jock who has lost half his height and is now taken down a couple notches. And Jack Black is honestly the best of them all. He made me laugh and smile. He plays the teen girl who is self absorbed and is phone dependent. He aced playing her. He was exactly like almost every teen girl today. Nick Jonas was a great surprise too. He was great at playing the 90's kid who said the 90's terms.
Overall I have seen this movie so many times now and I still laugh and love it.

title: A fun, family friendly, comedy adventure film
text: JUMANJI was a fun film from the middle 1990's, starring the late, great ROBIN WILLIAMS. And, when I heard that they were making a sequel to this film 22 years later and starring Dwayne "The Rock" Johnson, I thought "no thanks" and even skipped seeking it out at movie theaters over the winter, even after I heard that it was "pretty fun".I finally caught up to it on a recent flight and I have to admit - I was wrong for skipping this film JUMANJI: WELCOME TO THE JUNGLE is a fun romp with The Rock ably filling the lead role, aided by a strong supporting cast.JUMANJI was about a board came come to life. JUMANJI: WELCOME TO THE JUNGLE has the same board game that morphs itself into a video game and when 4 High Schoolers stumble across it while serving detention, well...comedy - and adventure - ensue.The four high schoolers are typical THE BREAKFAST CLUB stereotypes. The nerdy boy, the hot girl, the jock boy and the dorky girl. When these four are transported into the game they take on the outward appearance - and skills - of their video game characters - the nerdy body becomes the dashing hero (Dwayne "The Rock" Johnson). The hot girl becomes the dumpy (male!) professor (Jack Black). The jock becomes the un-athletic short kid (Kevin Hart) and the dorky girl becomes the kick-ass girl (Karen Gillan). It is the 4 actors playing their high school counterparts in their bodies that is the core of this film - and the center of the charm and fun of this film. All 4 shine. Johnson and Hart (back together after CENTRAL INTELLIGENCE) show that the chemistry they showed with each other in the previous film is no fluke. Gillan (Nebula in the GUARDIANS OF THE GALAXY films) shows that she can do kick-ass well - and with a wink in her eye. But it is the performance of Black that steals things. Someone said to me that Black was made to play a "hot high school girl" and I would have to agree. He almost steals the movie.Director Jake Kasdan (the TV series NEW GIRL) understands what kind of film that he is making, so keeps the fun and action going at a superficial, almost cartoon level, never really stopping to breathe (or to think). He keeps things light - and family friendly - with just enough "almost" dirty jokes to keep young and old alike interested. It earns - but never crosses the line - of it's PG-13 rating. There is talk of a sequel, and I, for one, am looking forward to it.Letter Grade: A-8 (out of 10) stars and you can take that to the Bank(ofMarquis

title: A Well Deserved Sequel
text: Jumanji: Welcome to the Jungle was one of the better sequels to spawn from Hollywood in recent years. Which is rare! And with an homage to the late Robin Williams, it was very special indeed.The story within a video game will surely get the attention of today's generation, and is also a complete 180 from the original. The best acting comes from Kevin Hart and Dwayne Johnson, they play off of each other with ease.Will there be a sequel? It is very likely!

title: Skeptical, but pleasantly surprised!
text:
I figured the first one could not be touched, but ten minutes in, I realized it's a totally different movie, with only the basic premise intact, which turned out not to be a bad thing. I see all these terrible reviews (about half) and can't help but wonder what those people were expecting. Seems like a bunch of hoity-toities who probably should go watch Titanic some more and stop trying to ruin the fun for would-be viewers.This movie had me laughing pretty hard. Those who said "stereotypical characters" obviously missed the point. Jack Black and Dwayne Johnson stole the show early on and everyone else rocked it as well.I can't help think but the ones who left poor reviews either don't like comedy or maybe don't enjoy the cast, which blows my mind. Maybe there was a little to be desired from the story, but it seems mainly for a younger audience, so...
Take it for what it is and try not to take it too seriously: IT IS A COMEDY, and it is very silly.I like the video game implementations and yes, that made it a little predictable, but didn't steal anything away from the possible enjoyment.
Killer movie. Not to be compared to the original movie, which seemed more aimed for kids, where this new version/sequel (?) was more aimed for comedy. I loved it.

title: Jack Black just makes this movie!
text:
I wasn't sure about this movie, being a huge Robin Williams fan and a fan of the original. But I was pleasantly surprised. All the actors did a fabulous job acting like they were "new" in their skin. And Jack Black took the prize for me. He brought the kooky, hilarious and sweetness of Robin Williams and put it on display for us all in a wonderfully hilarious performance.
Years ago I used to also think Jack Black was only good for slap stick comedy. But he has become one of my favorite actors. From The Holiday, to The Clock Hidden in the Wall, to Jumanji, he is so versatile.And I thought they did a great job continuing the Jumanji story. Honoring R.W. with the side note to the home he made in the Jumanji world. And they did a great job exploring how devastating the game can be to ones left behind, and to ones left inside.It was so funny, I can only imagine Robin looking down and laughing like crazy as well!So proud of a Sony for doing an amazing job at making a movie worthy of the original.

title: Destroying a childhood memory
text: Thanks for this attempt to destroy my childhood memories, I will pretend that I didn't watch it. The whole storyline makes no sense at all, I am happy that none of the old cast got involved.

title: It's a really good time
text: I really enjoyed watching this movie. It knows what it is and what it wants to be and executes it very well. The humor actually lands and makes you laugh, and it was really fun to see all of these actors out of their type casts' (except for Kevin Hart). I remember not really liking the original as a kid because I thought it was boring, so I didn't bother to watch this until four years after it came out, and its MUCH more entertaining. It moves at a fast-pace, with the perfect balance of team-building, comedy and action. And yes, they could've gone a little deeper with some of the relationships, but you aren't here to watch that. You're here to watch a cool, action-packed adventure movie, with high stakes and entertaining dialogue and humor. The only real fault I see, is the villain who was pretty boring and just creepy and one-dimensional in my opinion, but it makes sense considering that most video game villains are one-dimensional guys, which is cool. All in all, great movie, highly recommend.

title: Not as scary as the original but that's probably a good thing
text: The 90s version of jumanji was meant to be an innocent comedic vehicle for Robin Williams but it was a bit more horrific than family fun when I watched it as a kid. I can honestly say the original gave me nightmares and I can't imagine that happening to the kids who watch the new franchise because there's a care to make sure the fun scenes aren't too fight-inducing. This leads me to believe that the original intent of Jumanji wasn't just as a nightmare-delivery vehicle but had aims for more wholesome entertainment.Like the old version with Robin Williams, this modern version runs the risk of simply being a star vehicle since Kevin Hart, Jack Black, and the Rock are all name brands that consume movies with their own persona. It's a pleasant surprise that the film can maintain an ensemble feel. The film's humor rarely relies on Kevin Hart's stand-up persona or Jack Black's stoner persona. Instead, the two are stretched outside of their muscle memory (Black has been doing this for ages but it's a bigger surprise in a good way Kevin Hart that he can do this) to serve a larger story.The film wisely begins with a breakfast club feel but moves away from it pretty quickly and doesn't necessarily make the characters antagonistic enough towards one another that they would need major walls broken down before them before the game starts. One of the outcasts and popular kids, in fact, used to be friends with one another.The film is full of adventure, camaraderie, and a certain amount of humor. It also has a lot of world-building or internal logic that can make a Summertime blockbuster deep enough to lend itself to multi-layered thinking.

title: Can't compare to first part, but awesome funny

title: Jumanji welcome to the jungle
text: Reboots can be tricky. While some click, most of them crumble under the pressure to shake off the barrage of comparisons that would be thrown at the movie. Last couple of years saw such horrible reboots like Jurassic World, The Mummy, Kong: Skull Island. But much like Spiderman: Homecoming, Jumanji succeeds to impress the viewers. Jumanji gets a modern age makeover where now instead of a board game it is a video game. Four teenagers with varying personalities are put together in a detention. Here they discover the Jumanji video game and enter the world of Jumanji as their avatars. Then starts the fun ride. There are enough plot holes like how did the video game end up in a high school from Alex's freak house. The movie uses time tested cliche - Four teenagers with some flaw realize their shortcomings when (literally) seen from some other's point of view. But the fun parts of the movie makes us forget them, at least till the movie ends.The movie does not take itself seriously, and that is a huge plus point. The plot of the movie is crazy, there are man eating albino (what?!) rhinos on one side and villainous henchmen with crazy mud racing bike skills on the other side. But such craziness has been ridiculed in the movie itself, which makes you fall in love with it more.The bigger plus for the movie has been the performance of the lead actors. All of them have created niche for themselves in the film industry. Jumanji has used such niche beautifully and built very funny characters. Parts where Dwayne Johnson(Spencer) stops to admire his own physique will have you in splits. Not to mention his hilarious display of 'smoldering intensity'. Kevin Hart is Kevin Hart and Jack Blake as a women in a man's body is perfect. Karen Gillan, who is this mean Nebula in MCU, comes up with a very charming performance.All in all, Jumanji is a movie that you can watch without any regret. It will make you gasp, wonder and laugh hysterically. It is definitely worth a watch.

title: The shame of being a traitor

title: Total waste of money and time
text: This is not Jumanji.. the producers just stole the name for the sake of marketing... No wonder it's clocking close to a billion dollars in collection. It's a waste of time and money. The director has not made any effort on the script or screenplay to make the movie interesting with surprises. It's a third rate movie according to me. Don't spend on watching this movie. You will regret as I am.

title: I will never judge a book(movie) by its cover(trailer)
text: This is perfect example of reboot/sequel, trying to br its complete different thing with some small but respectful reference to Robin Williams' Classic Jumanji. If they did the same board game then people would be comparing and complaining.I like these kind of sequels, other movies that try to different than original were Cars 2, Ralph Breaks Internet; but those weren't great themselves but Jumanji:Welcome to the Jungle stands on its own feet.Great casting choices. Jack Black has so much fun playing Bathany and the pee scene is one of the best comedy scene I have seen in a while. Rock and Hart has great comedy ( btw I hated central intelligence). Karen Gillan, her introvert counterpart, trying to be sexy and kick ass was hell of a lot of fun. Her complaining about tiny cloths are some great meta jokes about entertainment industry.Story and plot progressing were bad but its a video game and the writers have so much fun taking liberties with it that I have no problems with that.Some good thrills were brought with the concept of 3 lives and game over. All 4 characters finding about themselves and discovering the new rules and mythology with the audiences were great. Rock,Karen and Jack brings something new to the table but Kevin Hurt plays himself, while some jokes did land pretty well.One of the most funniest, highly entertaining comedies of this time.

title: Feels like watching a video game with real actors!
text: There have been quite a few attempts at making movies out of games, or movies where the characters are playing the game. Jumanji sets a great standard on what all to do in such a movie. First and foremost, this is not a movie that is related much to the original Robin Williams movie. The game itself is the only thing in common between the two, and that too is a cameo. So the game transforms itself into a video game to lure the young of today who are no longer interested in board games. So we have 4 high school kids who happen to find this game and end up being stuck into to, having to win it in order to get back to their real lives.1. The first thing that will impress anyone is that the characters are independent of what your true self is. The characters in the game are the avatars which the players choose to be. So we have a nerdy, thin, afraid, kid Spencer transform into D. Smolder Bravestone (Dwayne Johnson) and so on. The characters are pretty well developed. They take time to adjust to the reality of the game, akin to Neo in the Matrix. They realize that they have powers they can harness and only need to be confident. At the same time they also have limitations set on their avatars by the game. So we can see Dwayne Johnson transform from being Spencer to Dr. Bravestone. The best of the four was perhaps Jack Black who did a great job at portraying an avatar (Prof. Shelly Oberan) of a girl, Bethanie, and all the learning that comes with the change of gender.2. The story line is pretty gamish, which is perfect. The game has not just transformed, it has evolved into a video game. There is a back story to the game that they are stuck in. And this game has levels which need to be cleared. Plus there are side characters in the movie who behave like characters in the game, in the sense that they only have a set of responses to give.3. The music of the move is somewhere in between of an action movie and an adventure movie, which you need if you have The Rock in an adventure film. It isn't grand, but gets the job done.4. First time movie director Jake Kasdan does a great job as far as the action part is concerned. The chase sequences are awesome, in particular the where the gamers have a herd of rhinos on their back. The sequence will get you on the edge of the seat and bite your lips! It was amazing to see how the characters evolve and they each have their strengths which come into the play. The best thing he does is make the movie very unpredictable. The riddles which the game gives to the players sound like one thing, but mean something completely different. And when the true meaning becomes clear to you and the characters, you can't just stop going "WOW!" The only thing I found lacking was the use of 3D and I think this would have made just as much impact in 2D. But maybe 3D is the thing to make action movies in these days.Overall it is a great movie to watch and do hit the theater to enjoy it the best.

title: Very bad adaptation
text: From the moment i saw board game transform into a game cartridge i knew that it will be bad, like bad bad. There was no action in the jungle what so ever, main villain of the movie was a joke, if someone asked me to describe him i could not say anything more than that he had one eye and was made of pests. Recently every movie that The Rock stars in is poor quality. This is a very disappointing movie, and don't let me start on CGI.

title: Entertaining and great fun
text: I really enjoyed this film. Yes, it's full of clichés like the nerdy and shy guy becoming the muscle who saves the day and the real-life muscle becoming awkward and insecure and then they realize that everyone has their own strengths and weaknesses and so on. There are also two girls who seem to despise the other's way of life and they also realize that the other isn't that bad after all. So yes, it's really basic setting with all that "emotional growth of characters" and "putting totally different and stereotypical people together and they learn to solve problems together" but still the film manages to be entertaining and great fun.The actors are great, they seem to have good connection and they work well together. Jack Black does good job as "Bethany". I usually don't like that much Jack Black's films, but he was really good choice for the role of irritating teenybopper. He really nails this part. I also liked Dwayne Johnson as Spencer. Dwayne Johnson is your typical video game hero, so he fits this role perfectly but I'm glad that his character wasn't just the flawless hero as such but made fun of him being such a beefcake and laughed at the stereotypes. If you are going to make a film with this stereotyped setting, you should be able to laugh at yourself and those stereotypes and this film does that. All those clichés weren't that annoying at all, because the film laughed at them also.For 9 or 10 stars this film should have had also some touching moments that make you cry and the characters should have been more compelling and real and not so stereotypical but all in all, this was entertaining, I liked the jokes and humor of this film and the actors do great job. Good family film that makes you laugh.

title: Although stocked with cliches the movie is a fun ride and a PERFECT sequel
text: The overlap with the original is all incredibly natural, the homages are subtle and the movie is enjoyable as a complete standalone with no previous knowledge. Great blockbuster movie, enjoyable for all ages, and a fun ride from start to finish with really good pacing.

title: quite sad - there was no story no wonderful scenes
text: I mean listen i loved the adventure style of the first jumanji and i know sequels never live up but this was really bad. it sucked. so. bad. it's based on a bunch of teens stuck in a jungle arguing. that is it. i know this isn't supposed to be a writing masterpiece and i love a fun blockbuster too but bewarned there is zero creativity. dont waste a good movie night because it has big names in the cast..

title: Great entertaining film, nostalgic 80's feel, funny and a rollercoaster!
text: I didn't think I would like this as I'm not the biggest fan of the Rock (only because he sin so much) but all the actors are cast really well and very funny. There's definitely a nostalgic 80's feel to this movie as well as modern take which appeals to all. The action was great and comedy was unexpected. title: Robin Williams is the only lucky one.
text: Sadly, Robin Williams is gone but it's a good thing he doesn't have to see this piece of rubbish. Turgid dialogue, juvenile acting, and a boring plot. Even Jack Black is wasted------playing a teen-age girl. It gives us virtually nothing new.

title: A clever sequel
text: The original Jumanji starring Robin Williams was great, but this movie is almost as good. The concept of modernising from a board game to a video game made it current, the cast assembled was great. I have to admit I've never been a massive Kevin Hart fan, but he excels in this film and the general mix of humour and action was brilliant. This is a superb family movie. A must watch.

title: Surprisingly good and funny!
text: I know the saying "Second parts are worse than first", so I wasn't too excited about this movie and thought "I bet they ruined it, a videogame? Seriously?". I'm so glad they proved me wrong!! You should not compare it to the first Jumanji, since this movie stands on its own. There are one or two references but that's all and it's ok. Jumanji now turned into a videogame that sucks players into it. It's not explained how or why this happened, but it's a magical game and if we can believe a stampede can come out of it, we can imagine suddenly turning itself into a videogame as the times changed. The teenagers are pretty much stereotypes, the jock, the nerd, the popular blond and the shy one. But once they are in the game, they change. The movie used this change for comedy and surprisingly, it works great!! Dialogues are really funny (and not dumb and cliched, and that's practically a miracle nowadays). Credit goes to the actors who play the videogame characters. They totally make you believe they are the teenagers in those avatars. And the game play is very well done. It's an old school adventure game, where characters have a item box where everything fits, the 3 lives are there, the non-player characters that repeat the same thing, secret passages, hints, the big boss, the map and stuff. It also has a "smoldering function" which comes out hilarious on screen. It's not as dark as the first, the animals were more dangerous and Van Pelt was vicious. This is a light comedy, and it works just great!

title: Perfect
text: One of the best comedies i have ever seen in my life, must see if you like to laugh a lot :)

title: If you have nothing better to do, why not?
text: Look I'll put this plainly, I saw this as a 19 year old male going to the cinema with his mum because she was complaining about not spending enough time with me. This is the only reason why, I have seen the original as well as the space themed rip-off Zathura, and this was the second worst (you can imagine which was the worst, begins with a Z and ends with suicidal thoughts). It was a largely depressing experience, it was painfully predictable and the slapstick humor was right out of an episode of Tom and Jerry. Jack Black brought the crude element to this which managed to force a few laughs out of me (the reason why this film made it to a 4).Watching Dwayne Johnson neck on with Karen Gillan (this was too predictable for anyone to consider it a spoiler) made my sick in my lap and hopefully some went in my mum's popcorn.As for the Rock and Kev combo we are seeing lately is overrated, and actually it should be left there because it doesn't deserve anymore thought. If you have some sort of pay monthly and see as many films as you want membership then please go and see this as you clearly have a lot of time on your hands. For those of us who only have one life, watch almost literally anything else.

title: Surprisingly awesome ... with 1 exception
text: As a child of the 90's I loved the original movie so I was very nervous when this remake was announced. But I found the movie to be fun & fresh while still keeping the spirit of the original, it's a great balance of humor, adventure & action with an intriguing story. Jack Black is by far the best & funniest character, he totally nails the part as a self absorbed teenage girl, yet brings something real to the character so she's not just your basic "popular high school girl" we've seen 1,000 times. Where Black brought depth to his stereotypical character Kevin Heart did the opposite, he played the high school jock character just as that, an arrogant jock who thinks he deserves everything handed to him. He's completely unlikeable & compared to the others his acting skills definitely need some work, he tries way too hard to stand out while the others shine effortlessly. I'm not typically a fan of the Rock's movies but his portrayal of a vulnerable nerdy kid stuck in this hyper masculine body is well rounded & believable, I was pleasantly surprised by his performance. Karen Gillian is the perfect as Ruby Roundhouse & has what is probably the funniest scene in the movie, her "sexy flirting" with the soldiers followed by her then kicking their asses is hilarious & awesome at the same time, it really sums up her entire character. Overall it's a fun movie I highly recommend, would be a 10 if it wasn't for Heart's performance.

title: Well, that was a surprise.

title: Nope...
text: I am a 90's kid, so I grew up on the original Jumanji with Robin Williams. I love the original! When I heard that there was going to be a remake, I thought "Oh, this better be good". Then when I saw the commercials for it, I knew I didn't want to see it, because I probably wasn't going to like it. I like Jack Black movies, but this 1 not so much. My mom and I were at Target and she grabbed the movie for was to watch. I really didn't want to. We watched it and yes, it was funny on some parts, but kind of boring. I thought the movie is or was going to be a movie for young kids. My 5 year old nephew wants to see Jumanji, but I don't know if I'd let him, unless I or other older kids or adults are with him. Quit a few curse words and something's I don't think he would understand. So, in the end I should have gone with my gut and said lets wait until this comes on TV. If you haven't seen the original, then you will probably like the remake.

title: Smoldering fun
text: Thought I would give this movie a chance, glad I did. I did not expect to enjoy it so much. I went into it thinking it would be some cheesy movie for 14 year olds (Power Rangers, anyone?), but found myself grinning the whole way through. The jokes are genuinely funny and really well-placed (smoldering, anyone?), not overdone or cringey, and delivered perfectly by all of the actors. Great chemistry, comedy writing, story and delivery.It's rare I'm pleasantly surprised by a movie. They really hit this one out of the park and the positive reviews definitely do it justice. Very enjoyable, still grinning as I write this!

title: Jumanji Has Nailed It
text: I've always tried not to watch those movies full of such humor. People have told me that if I watch them, I'll never be able to stop watching them, and I'd laugh for hours and never stop. But this time, I just had to try. And it was true. I laughed my head off. This movie is very relatable. Even though it isn't the most meaningful movie ever, not every movie is meant for that. A dry sense of humor, Dwayne Johnson has done it again. This was a hilarious and acceptable movie. Welcome to one of the comedies of your life.

title: That was a very pleasant surprise.
text: Well this was quite a surprise for me. I saw the first Jumanji, that was okay, even though I don't like Robin Williams. But seeing Dwayne Johnson was in this sequel my expectations were not very high, because he's not one of my favorite actors either. So the least I could say was that my expectations for this movie were very low. And it didn't begin good at all with the very annoying character played by Madison Iseman. But once they all been sucked up in the game it all became different, and in a real good way different. The genious about the story was putting the younger characters in totally opposed characters as grown-ups. The Rock as the shy nerd Spencer, the little Kevin Hart as the normally big popular athlete, the fat Jack Black as the highschool blonde sex bomb Bethany, the martial art expert Karen Gillan as the normally shy nerdy girl. Their characters were just hilarious when discovering their new abilities and body transformations while in their minds they were still the teenagers they were before. That is the best part of the movie, it worked very well, and it goes on during the entire movie. The story is more than enjoyable, with a good plot and very good special effects. Definitely better than the first Jumanji, and that's rare that a sequel is better than the first movie. For the moment Jumanji has been the surprise of the year for me. Not by being the best movie I saw, but by the fact I was expecting an average movie and that it turned out the quite opposite that I thought.

title: An exceptionally mediocre movie
text: It is quite amazing how such a movie will get to meet its budget and then make some in profits and who is to blame remains an unresolved mystery. How can someone in good faith give a positive review is an insult to the previous generation of movie creators that have worked to their best to give moviegoers a quality time and not just please the average Joe and make the most money while doing so. As a movie Jumanji: Welcome to the Jungle does not make your money worth at all, nor does it have anything artistic about it, and as long as everyone gets their paycheck movies like this one will continue to be made. Whatever passes is good to be shot as a movie I guess, and even more worrisome standards have gotten to record low in the industry, and have been doing so for some time now. I obviously discourage anyone to go pay and see this movie. Acting was alright, but the story and the script are as hallow as they get, and the movie is barely children friendly as well.

title: Sony... I have faith in you

I now feel this movie is better than the original.The first Jumanji movie didn't even bring us into the game, but rather had the game in the real world. While I do like that idea, the new Jumanji movie did better in the grand scheme. They actually brought us into the game, and they give us a goal to achieve in order to win. There is a lot of comedy, but they know when it's necessary. The action is great, and the actors do great. title: A Surprise Hit
text: This was perhaps the most surprising movie of 2017, especially in terms of box office. The whole idea of a movie poking fun at the tropes, clichés, and stereotypes of video games seems like the type of humor that would get old quickly, and the fact that it came out the week after Last Jedi made it seem like they weren't expecting a financial success. But lo and behold, it won 4 weekends at the box office and grossed $400,000,000 in the U.S alone. Given that popular franchises have been dominating the box office lately, it was nice to see something so original. Granted, it is a sequel, but it doesn't have many connections to the 1995 movie. It really is much more of a standalone work. It immerses itself in its own world and doesn't connect very much to the original Jumanji. It doesn't feel like a sequel to anything.It features the talents of Dwayne "The Rock" Johnson, Kevin Hart, Karen Gillan, and Jack Black. What's so great about these characters are how well they act like the kids who are controlling them. At the beginning, the kids fall into the stereotype zone: the nerd, the jock, the valley girl, and the shy girl. Despite that, the way they interact with each other in their in-game avatars makes up for it and makes them fully fledged characters as opposed to just generic tropes. Most of the humor is stemmed from the idea of someone being in the body and role of someone completely different from them, which is why it works. It's really just classic role-reversal. As for the story, though, it's kind of generic. They need to find this mystical gem and bring it to a jaguar statue before some generic bad guy does. But it's the story isn't really the appeal of this movie, it's about the characters. The jungle looks nice, which is an added bonus.Another thing this movie does very well is how well it represents the video game aspect. You don't need to be a gamer to understand or enjoy this. Anything that general audiences wouldn't understand is simply explained, meaning that anyone can enjoy this. Also, the idea of the NPCs just repeating lines of dialogue to the Rock was very accurate to the idea of a real RPG, making it seem like Jumanji could very well have been a game from back in the day.This is a movie that's on the verge between "guilty pleasure" and "legitimately good." I'd say it's the latter, although it does have elements of the former. It knows exactly what it is and does a very good job at it; it's just a fun comedy about teenagers taking on a new set of roles and forming new bonds as a result. It's fun, it's satisfying, and there's really nothing more to it.

title: Ridiculous Family Fun,
text:
Jumangi: Welcome to the Jungle is a great movie with a very well developed plot and a terrific comedic cast. It is a very enjoyable, fresh continuation to the first Jumangi movie that, instead of being a straight up carbon copy to the original, it merely takes the concept and expands upon it in a new, interesting way. We see a group of teenagers get transported in to a video game and the adventure that ensues is as engaging as it is funny. The only major issue I had with the movie is that they had a very lackluster villain. I think Bobby Cannavale is a good actor, but there was absolutely nothing interesting for him to do with this character, there was no scope or development put in to him whatsoever. The cast is terrific and all deliver performances that are immensely unique to what they have done in the past. Dwayne Johnson as a nerdy teen, Kevin Hart as a nervous jock, Karen Gillan as a shy girl, and Jack Black as a loud, confident teenage girl all made this movie extremely ridiculous and impossible not to enjoy, they all brought it 100 percent to their part, and looked like they were having a good time. A very honorable reboot. An unexpected delight, Jumangi: Welcome to the Jungle is great fun that I would recommend to anyone looking for a good family film. 
Four tennagers get transported in to a video game and must save the island of Jumangi to leave, but they only have three lives each. 
Best Performance: Jack Black

title: Fun!!
text: Perfect casting! Actors were great!! So much fun to watch for the whole family!

title: A Future Classic
text: When I first saw this film I was convinced that I would hate it. I mean, firstly, who the hell did they think they were taking a well loved classic and giving it a reboot anyway? And into a Video Game no less? And then . . . And then they populated it with actors that 9 times out of ten I am really not a fan of (Not Karen Gillan, she's great!). These are people who play caricatures of themselves all the time. But do you know what? That worked perfectly. I can't think of any other actors that could have taken on these roles and made them their own like Dwayne, Jack, Kevin and Karen did, taking the pi$$ out of their own ego's and "flaws" throughout.In some ways this edition of Jumanji is superior to the first. It has far better CGI and it actually takes you in to the game instead of the game coming out to you, but it would obviously be nowhere without Mr Williams and that team leading the way.I really like the Video Game references that even an old fart like me can recognise and it is incredibly fun. Just as easy to watch as the original and I'm sure it will last the course just as well.It's a look so really strange that 'Baby I Love Your Way' by 'Big Mountain' fits in to this film in such a great and fun way.There's action, there's comedy, a bit of romance and a general feel good vibe.I am a bit concerned that they rushed into a further sequel so quickly and I am prepared to be disappointed when I get to see it, but I would also love to be surprised as I was by this one.

title: Lazy script, actors did their best with what they got
text: This is one of those films that's designed for a big audience and is therefore measured to appeal to most. In essence there is nothing wrong with that. It can still result in a wonderful family film. But it's problematic when the movie feels like its made with an easy ingredients recipe by a chef that forgot to put some flavor in.All the elements that made the original film a succes (and to some a classic) are present, but the narrative is put together with so little imagination that I felt like I was watching a movie I'd seen a hundred times before. And you know what, they could get away with it - if the gags were better and the character's weren't made out of cardboard.Don't get me wrong. There are funny moments. I laughed hard a couple of times, but regardless this whole movie felt like a missed opportunity. The Rock is great as Spencer aka Dr. Bravestone, an anxious nerd made jungle hero. The way The Rock pulls out some signature looks and plays with insecure mannerisms made me think back of his hilarious performance in Be Cool. Kevin Hart has his funny moments, but he's essentially playing himself, not getting much further than delivering some sas and tiny man rants here and there. Karen Gillan gives us the best performance and Jack Black is trying hard to be funny but the whininess of the high school princess he plays makes it a difficult task to pull off. How did you screw that up guys? Jack Black is inherently hilarious.The characters lack grit and the friction between the protagonists is too weak. It's not because you're making an adventure film that kids can go see that the emotional world of the characters shouldn't be tangible. It all feels very childish, the dialogue and the performances. It's clear that this is because of the script and the direction, The Rock and friends didn't get much to work with.I was also pretty disappointed in terms of cinematography. It's all kind of bland, just like the characters. The bad guys and the ending get the coolest lighting.When you can work at a story that puts teenagers in the middle of a magical adventure land, that gives you the opportunity to play with animals, bad guys, friendship and time in an interesting way, you need to do more with it!

title: A solid, fun and imaginative movie!
text: Who wouldn't want to watch a reboot of the 90s classic Jumanji starring Dwayne "The Rock" Johnson, Kevin Hart and Jack Black? Throw in Nick Jonas and Karen Gillian and you have yourself one of the most exciting ensembles for an action-comedy. It is a fun and innovative repackaging of the original Robin Williams starrer set in the 21st century. Perennially underrated Jack Black is just marvellous in the film. It is worth watching just for his performance.

title: Surprisingly great adventure flick
text:
I avoided the film for a long time. First of all I did like the first Jumanji but did not nescessairly think it deserved or needed a sequel. Then I wasn't quite sold on this sequels potential even when it became a major hit I just thought it as just another Hollywood cash cow. 
Now I finally gave it a try and I am glad I did. The film turns out to be one of the most entertaining features of 2017 with a major rewatch-effect.
The story works because even though it is modern and works on modern action and humor it still has something nostalgic added to it which made it very appealing. Also the way the characters are written is that they could easily have been of a 90s film (more or less). I loved the idea that some kids become their total opposite Avatars in the video game. Also their relations made the film more interesting than its special effects which is another reason it worked.
The adult actors played well and most of them actually played with their own image. There was. lot of self irony attached. Really loved Dwayne Johnson who gives one of his better performances. Kevin Hart was sometimes a bit annoying but it worked with his character. Jack Black was easily the MVP. He cracked me up every time he was on screen. Such a clumsy performance, but in a good way. Karen Gillan was also great and totally unlike her most famous Marvel character. The special effects were good. The action worked. The ending was touching. All those elements made it to one of the best adventure flicks of last year.

title: Family movie...

I enjoyed the interpretations of Dwayne Johnson who played as Spencer, Jack Black who played as Bethany and he was simply hilarious, Kevin Hart who played as Fridge and Karen Gillan who played as Martha. I highly recommend everyone to watch this movie because I am sure that you will laugh a lot and you will have a great time watching it.
