title: Completely Unexpected Reboot - Excellent
text: As a big fan of the original Jumanji, I didn't expect this movie to deliver. But in its own charming way, it managed to prove me wrong. The Rock is excellent, as in any of his other movies. The story revolves around teenage problems and a spooky video game. In the process, we get to know all the characters - who each have their own unique ways of looking at things (which really reminded me of "The Breakfast Club"). In fact, this movie felt like a direct throwback to that film.If you liked "The Breakfast Club", then this version of Jumanji is perfect for you. It's funny, filled with action and adventure, and has tons of interpersonal dynamics and "therapy session growth" type moments throughout. I highly recommend this movie.

title: Very enjoyable film.
text:
As someone who is not a die hard fan of the original, I was really looking forward to watching it. And this movie delivers exactly what it advertised. FUN. Jack Black, The Rock, Kevin Heart, and Karen Gillian are perfect for this movie. VFX looks great.
Movie briefly deals with self image and social anxiety issue of the main characters and handles it fine. This movie feels like those campy adventure movies.

title: Also missing - the magic & mystery of the original
text: 22 years after the original jungle-themed, perilous board game unleashed its magic in theaters, we see what happens when the game gets an upgrade as a video game in 'Jumanji: Welcome to the Jungle.' This time around, four detention-prone high schoolers stumble upon a retro cartridge gaming system and somehow are transported into the land of Jumanji, where they must lift the curse of a stolen jewel known as the "eye of the panther" if they are to have any chance at an escape.Unlike the Robin Williams-starring original, which was a bit more serious than it was silly, the crew here ratchets up the funny factor thanks to the likes of Kevin Hart, Dwayne Johnson and a flamboyant Jack Black (as the young Bethany is stuck in his avatar), while Karen Gillan tries to balance things out as Martha (a.k.a., Ruby Roundhouse, killer of men). Of course, half of the humor comes from the fact that the four teens are caught in bodies that aren't their own - with some of the gags feeling either over the top or severely immature (see Bethany as Black's Dr. Shelly Oberon). There are a few scenes that are worth the cost of admission, namely one that involves pound cake, but overall the movie is a wild ride of laughs that are targeted at adolescent boys and unnecessary casting of Nick Jonas targeted at adolescent girls.What's missing in 'Jumanji' is the magic from the first entry in the series, which was a bonafide action-adventure ride that really sucked you into the game. Sure, this one was a massive hit with audiences, and is spawning a sequel. But it's nothing really special - even the attempts to show there are learnings and lessons of acceptance, bravery and living the one life we have to live come across as being afterthoughts, or at worst, hollow.'Jumanji: Welcome to the Jungle' isn't awful - there are highlights here and there, but it's definitely overrated and a wasted opportunity.

title: The definition of Cliché and Cheese
text: The main problem here is that the film is filled with typical cheesy lines, as well as predictable plot lines. This essentially wastes the comedic talents of Kevin Hart and Jack Black, and Karen Gillan's character is far from the flippant and sassy character of Amy Pond that people tend to expect. What we end up getting is just run of the mill characters with no depth, acting as stand-ins. Anyways, the plot line seems to be forced (the tension between Spencer and Fridge seems to have arisen out of nowhere, same w the affection between Spencer and Martha). Ironic that a movie with a video game theme has a worse storyline than games such as WoW or Starcraft.

title: Get out of the jungle
text: I saw the original Jumanji as a kid and remember how exciting, serious, funny and scary at times that movie was. A real adventure starting with an unknown mysterious object was an invitation to a kids Adventure.Now , more than 20 years later they turned that into a silly over the top action movie with literally no mystery. A terrible start with the rejection of the original Board Game which had to be turned into a videogame - why? Is a mysterious boardgame not appealing to children these days? If so, Is this not a children's movie but a silly want-to-be-comedy for adults that remember the old gem of a movie? And if that is the case, why is the content delivered as dumbed down as possible and with actors mostly middle aged men can relate to (exception to the rule is the hot girl Roundkick for sure). Come on, why not give new actors a chance? I for myself cannot imagine showing this much useless action and harsh violence at times to my kids below 12. So are Teenagers really only engaged if they can knot ties to a video game nowadays? Isn't there "Ready player one" for that genre already? Please enlighten me on what the target audience is supposed to be.The plot is really easy. Straight line which resolves itself when stuck. Not much more to say about that. The movie ties action scene after action scene without real leverage or mystery. That reminds me, why was the game changed, if the source of all is the old board game. Weird.In between make the world more understanding and aware of young people problems. Of course the writers had to rub in some morals of sexuality, self conscience, friendship and what not. But... oh no, don't let the audience think for just a second but deliver all with cringy dialogues at absolutely the wrong timings.What else: They should have used a different title for the movie, like: "This is not Jumanji as you know it" or "Jumanji - watch the original"What was good: The budget. One scene was remotely funny. The detention Teacher.At last a question for people with basic knowledge of physics: Can a helicopter fly on its side?

title: Lost the spark of what Jumanji is
text: The original film was like a first foray into horror films for children. It was at times frightening, with the creepy idea that you could be sucked into a board game and have to survive in a merciless jungle until someone sets you free. Much like the original Jurassic Park, it perfectly balanced fantasy and horror with a bit of comedy peppered in to alleviate some of the more tense moments. Jumanji: Welcome to the Jungle throws all of that out the window, and turns it into a cartoony, campy comedy film. While the film does have laughs and can be entertaining at times, it's just a shame to see such a fun idea turn into a joke with no consequence or terror to anything happening to the characters. While it may seem nitpicky to say, it just has no heart. The original was fraught with sadness for Alan as he returns from the horrifying jungle to find his parents died pouring their life savings into finding their son. I don't want to see the Rock flexing every other minute while Kevin Hart quips in between for an entire film. This film is a Jumanji film by name only.

title: Very very bad
text: A friend recommended me this movie and... very very bad. A kind of comic "Scary movie" in the jungle with very bad argument.

title: Good Performances, Not Much Else
text:
Acting-9/10
Script/Writing-6/10
Special Effects-7/10
Characters and Character Development-7/10

Cinematography-6/10Overall- 6.7/10

title: Severely lacking in charm and nuance from the get-go.
text:
It keeps desperately being pulled between the creativity and fourth-wall winking rebootquels of 21 Jump Street and the angsty, dark, teen, Michael-Bay-but-by-way-of-TV-movie most recent Power Rangers type films.
And by being pulled in these two directions it ends up sitting directly in the middle and ending up being almost entirely bland. The uninspiring locations and effects don't even have the zip and pep of Zathura, Jumanji's semi-sequel, and it carries none of the atmosphere, dread and unique tone of the original Jumanji. It's another in a long line of 'videogamey'-inspired films written or producer-curated by people who have absolutely no below-surface knowledge of actual videogames.
The cast is wasted, the gags and concept potential untapped and there's absolutely no subtlety. It sort of seems like a weird joint jungle comedy central roast where everyone is making fun of each other. It's by the numbers, unsurprising, and no less flaccid than any of the trailers made it look. Also the music is rubbish.
I give it one star for Karen Gillan's constant videogame pose. She did her research.

title: I really must be missing something here
text:
First off, I cannot tell which age group this was geared towards. 
Second, I may be a bit harsh because I am grading with no curve - the first installment had Robin Williams, a master of comedy. This one had Kevin Hart and The Rock, who together could never be as funny as Robin Williams by himself.
Third, there were so many political intro's in the film that it felt a bit smarmy.
Fourth, I totally get the CGI bit in modern movies, but it has to make SOME sense on SOME level. Several fails in this movie here.
I guess asking for any character development is a bit much for an action/comedy, but I will still ask, and there was minimal, if any, chemistry in this movie. 
Probably best for the 12-17 crowd.

title: Great potential - great failure
text: They had it all. Promising actors and excellent story, but they spoiled a great opportunity.This movies has nothing of the magic the 1995 version had. The trailer gives the allure of adventure, comedy and action - a good combo. It does not deliver anything and is just another forgettable teen flick.It is hard to feel anything for the characters and building suspense is hard when you care less if it goes bad.If you haven't seen the real Jumanji yet I highly recommend seeing that one instead of wasting a couple of hours on this.

title: Just wholesome, comfortable family fun
text: Overall this movie is very fun, but there are a lot of below the belt gender jokes that I wasn't too fond of. What video game character has to pee? It also doesn't have the heart of the original. The video game twist was a fun idea on how to make it more modern, but lots of people still play board games. Also, they figured out the premise really fast. The game flops back and fourth between the characters acting like their real world selves and having the abilities of their video game selves whenever it is convenient for the plot or comedy. Even though it felt a bit predictable to me and Karen Gillan seemed really uncomfortable in her costume I did still enjoy watching The Rock run around in the jungle.

title: Good watch to multi-task
text: Formula movie. You can watch on and off and not miss a thing. The stereotype norms are abundant that continue the White dominated norms; Black dumb jock,...

title: For Mindless Entertainment, it's OK
text: Jumani: Welcome to the Jungle is nothing special. It has some charismatic performances in all of the main characters, although Dwayne Johnson and Kevin Hart definitely take the cake. But besides some of the natural charisma of the actors, I found most of the jokes to be very hit or miss, the script bland and the special effects weren't even that good. The script is mainly a way to get from point A to point B and the things that happen in the middle are kind of predictable and boring. Also, the movie could have easily been 20 minutes or so shorter. Anyway, it's not terrible, it does have a few good laughs and it kept me relatively entertained for most of it.

title: It's Fine
text: Jumanji: Welcome to the Jungle exists.I am neither upset nor pleased by that fact, even after this rewatch. Trust me, based off of the trailers and especially the slanderous hallmarks behind the production of this movie's division (director Jake Kasadan, Nick Jonas being assigned an ACTUAL role, and possibly sitgmatizing Robin Williams's legacy!!!) this movie could've been a LOT worse. But...it's unusually not? It's culpable, wild, adventurous, role-reversal, cheesy, Crocodile Dundee buffoonery. The delirious paradox of it all however, is that it works, but it also, jointly, doesn't work. Fin. Verdict Change: (C+ -> C)

title: An enjoyable fresh take on the classic film
text: Jack Black is the most enjoyable character, acting his part extremely convincingly. The remainder were either less capable or less entertaining while playing their supposed roles, but each one still brought their own handful of laughs. Despite the imaginative setup, the movie quickly becomes predictable, but it's still worth a watch for a light comedy.

title: manages to make the most of a familiar setup
text: Belated, stand-alone sequel to the late Robin Williams 1995 original about a mystical board game is effectively updated for today's audiences as the film chronicles four teenagers (your prototypical nerd, jock, queen bee, and outcast) who--with shades of The Breakfast Club--are sentenced to detention where they begin playing an old video game. Unfortunately for them the video game is much more than it appears to be and they're "transported" into the game world where they're forced to make the most of their precarious predicament. The formulaic approach and clichéd themes aside, this is actually a pretty good showing with laugh-out loud humor, nifty visual effects, clever plot twists, and thrilling action scenes, elevated by the work of an excellent cast, especially Johnson and Black who are deliberately "uncomfortable in their own skin." It doesn't cover much new ground, but it's still pretty fun regardless. **½

title: This is not a remake.....more a continuation
text: 28 December 2017First Film of Choice at The Plaza Dorchester Today - Jumanji. This film is not a remake, it is a continuation and begins with a link paying homage to the original. We then see that as technology gets upgraded so does the concept of Jumanji. Whereas we first saw the board game unleashing its malevolence on the world, this time the players are sucked into the jungle world of the game itself. There are echoes of The Breakfast Club in this production in that we have a group of high school kids who are very far removed from each other socially thrown together in detention. They are then sucked into the game where they discover they have to work together to survive. They are transformed into characters that are the exact opposites of the real them and each one has to realise that being this far out of their comfort zone is the key to utilising their assigned skill sets in order to survive. This film was fast paced, gritty, humorous and very cleverly written bringing out some great performances from the main characters. Dwayne Johnson isbecoming a darn fine actor and Jack Black never fails to please. This is definitely one for the DVD collection.e

title: Classicly done, a pleasant surprise!
text: Since Hollywood started using itself as a liberal propaganda machine I stopped watching movies coming out of there and rather watch International productions instead, but 'Jumanji: Welcome to the Jungle' was a fresh breath of the good old times with no politics, pc all that crap, just pure and classic fun.Most people seem to enjoy this movie by the looks of it, though I think 'Gamers' will enjoy and understand the twists, puns and jokes for the extra star. It's not an epic movie, but it is very good, it's silly but in a good way and not cheesy, it's classic but not cliché and it makes fun of a certain group of people that's been zombie'ing around society with their phones for years.Story is straight up, on the rails but what some fails to understand that this is the story of an old video game thus you were herded quite hard in to a certain line of action and you just had to go with it without much freedom. Humor is funny and the actors compliment each other quite well, good crew and good directing.For those of you that are weary of today's Hollywood I can wholeheartedly recommend this movie as it'll make you feel the past two decades didn't impact it at all. Great, light, fun with lots of laughs. Enjoy. :-)

title: Love to watch this movie
text: Jumanji: Welcome to the Jungle is an improvement over the Robin Williams film which is a surprise. Directed by Jake Kasdan(son of Lawrence Kasdan)Jumanji is funny, well-paced and entertaining. However, it is the performances- especially Jack Black who plays a gender confused entity and Dwayne Johnson who plays a man low on esteem (the opposite of how he is IRL) which make this film a joy to watch. Kevin Hart and Karen Gillan ably support, and some great special effects make sure that this is one movie you'd be talking for some time.

title: A Far Cry From The Disaster I Was Anticipating
text: A direct sequel to Jumanji that also serves as a reboot of sorts, Jumanji: Welcome to the Jungle is far from a high-quality popcorn entertainer but it somehow does manage to fare better than what everyone's expectations was from it. Despite its insipid premise, this adventure-fantasy works, thanks to the camaraderie & witty banter between its cast.Directed by Jake Kasdan, the story sounds like a recipe for disaster on paper with really dumb moments in store and yet the director is able to derive a pretty good mileage out of it in the end. The tone remains lighthearted, there's a sense of fun to how the events unfold, and the cast sure seems to be having a blast as evident in their respective renditions.As for the performances, the sum of parts is greater than the whole here and it's the actors' collective effort than any individual act that steers the movie past the finish line. There are stakes in play but since all characters are one-dimensional & uninteresting, one doesn't really care. What gives it a refreshing touch however is the dissonance in who they are & what they are supposed to be.Overall, Jumanji: Welcome to the Jungle does what it set out to do and makes for an amusing, entertaining & fun-filled extravaganza that will satisfy most if not all. The film doesn't aim for anything big, never takes itself seriously, is well-aware of its limitations, and delivers a lighthearted romp with honesty & passion. A far cry from the disaster I was anticipating, this blockbuster is more pleasant than it had any right to be.

title: Can't Wait to Watch Again
text: This is one of the funniest movies I have seen in a long time. The actors were so believable!

title: Movie in a video game
text:
This is quite interesting movie which shows what would happen if one day we could get into video games and play. The story is funny and ALL of the characters are good.
There are some ambiguous things, but I guess you shouldn't look for too much logic here.

title: I happily admit that I was very-pleasantly surprised
text: "Okay," sez me, "what could you possibly do to top (RIP) Robin Williams?" The answer, as it turned out to be, was to treat the story entirely differently: after a nod to the original concept by showing the original game in the (once again, "resurfaced to the sound of ominous drums") original box, let the next re-opening of that same box show a 1990's game-cartridge. And then, let the fun begin again.But this treatment went much farther - and, much better - than "just that original trope." The players are now trapped in a video-game, and when they arrive in that game, not only are they adults but one of them (played by Jack Black) went from female to male! (Yes, there are the expected nods to that anatomical change ... both of them ... but, they were tastefully and cleverly done.)The concept that the actors were stuck in a video game, and that all of them knew it, and that all of them remembered throughout where they had actually came from and who they really were, was expertly done. In short, this is a very well-crafted SCREENPLAY.The actors - both youth and adult - were well-directed and played their respective parts to the hilt, never forgetting that "it is all in fun."The musical score is also well-conceived, right down through the final credits-roll. (But I admit that I was hoping to see "a hidden scene," not just a final beating of the drums, when the film finally ran to its last frame!)In short - "I thoroughly enjoyed it, far more than I thought that I would." It certainly stands -alongside- the previous movie, when I very frankly came into the theater anticipating that it could not. "Well done."

title: GREAT
text: Very fun and entertaining. Great modern twist on the orignial story.
